Minister, is it true that your department has published a study since the election which concludes that compulsory work for the dole would not work? Did your department brief you prior to this weekend on the benefits of work‐for‐the‐dole schemes? If so, has the department commented on what success rates such schemes would have in finding young people permanent employment? Minister, did the Prime Minister consult you about this poll‐driven diversion before his announcement on the Sunday program yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Faulkner for his question. Yet again we have a demonstration by the opposition in the questions that they put forward that they have not accepted one key fact that they must accept: they cannot accept that they ended up being a bad government that generated very high levels of unemployment, for which the community has not forgiven them nor will it forget. That is the first thing they have to recognise.

ANSWER.PARA: They want to come to the table and redesign the programs, when they were given 13 years to do this job and on each occasion muffed it up. Finally the community gave up on them and rejected them. They are the party that were rejected. The second point that is clear from this question is that even in opposition Labor is not prepared to look positively at what should be done vis‐a‐vis unemployed Australia. Their own Working Nation program failed and then they have—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections on my left. The minister is entitled to have the opportunity to answer the question.

—They have carped and they have been negative about every proposal we have put forward, which is extraordinary from people who were such abject failures in government themselves. Let me move from those two basic comments to the question asked by Senator Faulkner. Senator Faulkner, I give you an undertaking that I will ascertain whether my department—
—Ha, ha!

—I will ascertain whether they have released a report that has the words that you quote in it. It might surprise you, but I do not think there was ever a minister in your party that carried around the exact words in every report that had ever been released in their portfolio.
—What are you talking about?

—You in particular. Coming to the substance of the matter, Senator Faulkner: if you are trying to imply that the Prime Minister has gone off and raised some policy proposal out of the blue, then you are so far out of field that you are absolutely lost. This matter was raised at the employment committee, of which I am a member, on a number of occasions. It has been discussed at that level on a number of occasions and it was clearly understood that the Prime Minister was going to raise this matter on the Sunday program last week. Can I ask you then, Senator, as you inquire of your department whether in fact they did publish such a study and what advice the department might have given you—because, of course, you have indicated that nothing would surprise you—perhaps you could also indicate, when you were consulted by the Prime Minister, as you allege you were, at the cabinet subcommittee, whether you would have alerted him to any of your department's assessments about the proposed effectiveness of the scheme and whether in fact it would have the capacity to find young people real jobs in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a misunderstanding on Senator Faulkner's part. May I first, Madam President, just remind you that yet again there is an implication in a question—that I allege I was consulted. If the senator wants to claim that I have lied, let him do so; otherwise I ask you not to let him gutlessly put an implication that a senator or a minister has lied when they have given an answer to a question—namely, that I was consulted. Senator Faulkner, I will look up the dates of the relevant committees for you. If it is of any particular interest, I may choose to pass them on.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to the matter which you have clearly not understood, the focus of this program is on young Australians—not exclusively young Australians, but there is a focus on them, particularly about 30,000 of those who have entrenched, long-term unemployment—and the benefit for those people to have the opportunity to give something back for the unemployment benefit that they receive. You might in principle refuse to accept that, but I tell you what: there are a lot of unemployed people out there who have consistently raised with members that they would like to do something in exchange for getting the unemployment benefit. They would like to do something, and this is a fair response to that. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. The minister has just announced approval for a production licence that will add 20 per cent to Australia's self-sufficiency in oil. Can the minister provide details of this development and in particular what does it signify in terms of investment confidence under the economic policies and management of the Howard government? What contribution can a development of this type make in the fight to wipe out the disgraceful foreign debt Australia was left with after 13 years of Labor?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Ellison for that question. I would like to confirm that I have approved a production licence in the Laminaria‐Corallina area in the Timor Sea. This production licence has been granted to Woodside at 50 per cent, BHP at 25 per cent and Shell at 25 per cent. It will mean the construction of a floating production storage and off‐loading facility in Australian waters in the Timor Sea. It represents an investment of $1 billion. There have been reserves proven up of 250 million barrels: 200 million in the Laminaria and 50 million in the Corallina. It will produce in the order of 150,000 barrels of oil a day, which will increase the self‐sufficiency of Australia by some 20 per cent. It is expected that the oil will come into production in 1999 and that the project will operate for some 14 years.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the question on balance of payments, and bearing in mind the foreign debt that was left to us by 13 years of Labor, it will contribute in the order of $1.8 billion per annum in export earnings. The speed with which this project has been approved reflects confidence in the Howard government and in the investment environment that we have put down.
The question which was asked was: what are the benefits for Australia? Of course, as I have mentioned, the major benefit is $1.8 billion in export income.

TALK.START.PARA: —We're going to export it; we're not going to consume it ourselves?

—What a dumb question. Senator Cook, it does not matter whether part exported or used domestically; it still has a $1.8 billion positive effect on our balance of payments and hence on our foreign debt. The project will be subject to Commonwealth resource rent tax and is expected to make a significant contribution in RRT. It has been estimated that the total project is valued at about $7 billion and the direct government take will be $2 billion.

ANSWER.PARA: Australian companies have a major opportunity to supply goods and services to the project, both in the construction phase and in the operational phase. I understand that there has already been, or is going to be, a contract let to a major Perth company. Laminaria will also establish infrastructure—I think this is very important—that could support the further development of petroleum projects in the region. For many years, of course, Australia was not looked on as being highly prospective. The fact that this project will go ahead will encourage further exploration and development and, hopefully, more finds of oil which will be of benefit to this country.

It is also worth mentioning that this floating oil production storage and off‐loading technology will, in fact, be the largest in the world, so we are starting to lead the world in this sort of technology. There is no doubt that this is but the beginning of the sort of investment that the public has been looking for with the election of the Howard government in March last year.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme: Science and Engineering

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Do you agree with your colleague, Minister—that is, Senator McGauran, the Minister for Science—that there is no doubt that Australia will be the loser if we do not encourage more people into science and engineering? Is increasing the HECS fee for science and engineering courses from $2,500 to $4,700 encouraging more people into science and engineering? Shouldn't you be creating incentives rather than disincentives? What precisely do you propose to do in response to the dramatic fall in enrolments for these courses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Carr, for that question, because it gives me the opportunity to address some misunderstandings in the community—presumably not peddled by yourself, although your past record is not that good. The preliminary analysis of applications for science is that there is no systematic impact of the changed HECS arrangements on science and engineering applications. In fact, in a number of universities, these have gone up. It is true that in others they have gone down, but they have, nonetheless, gone up. The trend—
—How many? Don't know.
—What are the overall figures?
—Order! There are other opportunities to ask questions and follow‐up questions and to take note of answers. The minister is entitled to answer the question she has been asked.

—Thank you, Madam President. The trend of a decline in the number of science applicants has been apparent for a number of years. This has been going on for two, possibly three, years. This is, therefore, either the third or fourth year when applications across the board may have fallen.

ANSWER.PARA: The causes for this are complex and long term, but they look very much linked to falling enrolment patterns in schools. For example, the proportion of year 12 students undertaking a physical science course has fallen from about 50 per cent in 1986. In 1986, about 50 per cent of year 12 students did a physical science course. It went down to 44 per cent in 1992. That was when Labor was in government. Just remember this: when you were in government federally, the proportion of year 12 students doing physical science fell from about 50 per cent to 44 per cent and then, in 1995, it fell to a mere 31 per cent.

It follows that, with a declining interest in physical science—the example I have cited in this case—at year 12 level, how can we possibly expect students to come on from year 12 and suddenly decide, not having done science in year 12, that they will enrol in science at university? This is just another legacy of Labor's bad management.

It is important to highlight that applications for university are not the same as enrolments. Between 1993 and 1996 the number of students commencing science and engineering courses actually increased; that is, applications fell but the places accepted at university actually increased. That was accomplished in part by drops in TER scores and cut‐offs in many courses. While it is still very early in the academic year, it appears that following the final round offers in New South Wales there are still some vacancies in science and engineering courses, but it is difficult to see a clear pattern in movements between 1996 in 1997 TER cut‐offs.

One of the concerns is not just that there has been a fall in science applications and a fall in interest in science at year 12—all generated when the people opposite were in government—which obviously leads to a fall in applications for science, but there is a greater problem and that is that brighter students are turning away from science. That has nothing to do with the HECS charges. A pattern over years, as I am advised, is that, across the board, brighter students are turning away. The Victorian government to their credit have recognised this and have set up a committee to see what they can do about it.

Do I agree that we will be a poorer society if we have proportionally fewer people doing science and engineering across the board? I would say yes. Science and engineering are vitally important faculties at universities, Senator Carr. You know that and I know that. But let us not pretend, with increased applications in some of the highest band level courses, that HECS has anything to do with it. Primarily, it is a function of students not taking science in year 12.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, in the past you have said that the dramatic drop in science enrolments was the fault of individual universities in the `light rush' of your funding cuts. Do I take it from today's answer that you now agree with your colleague Mr McGauran who says that a lack of science grounding in schools is to blame? I ask you again, Minister, what are you going to do about the fall in enrolments in science and engineering at university?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I answered the original question that Senator Carr asked. To the extent that we end up with falling enrolments across the board, that would be a matter of concern understandably. I would hope that each of the states would be prepared to work cooperatively, take up the sort of initiative very wisely taken by Minister Honeywood in Victoria, to recognise what is going wrong—why aren't students doing science in year 12? I will work cooperatively with each of the state ministers to address that problem.

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Heffernan, for that question. You are quite right, Senator Heffernan; when Labor left government youth unemployment was creeping towards 30 per cent. That was a lower level, incidentally, than the highest level we have had, which is 34.8 per cent under the previous Labor government. You are quite right, Senator Heffernan, to say that people opposite still do not understand why they were not re-elected. They mistakenly think the electorate got it wrong. They think the electorate is stupid. They have put no faith in the Australian people electing a different government to fix the mess that they in fact created. As Senator Heffernan says, there was no remorse, no regrets, no apologies—just the relevance deprivation syndrome.

ANSWER.PARA: Labor was in power for 13 years and it had not managed to get youth unemployment down below 25 per cent for each of its final five years in government. The coalition has an absolute determination to address this problem. I did raise last week the Leader of the Opposition's attitude to young unemployed people. This was the Beazley `at least they are not on the street bothering other people' line.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Beazley.

—The line that Mr Beazley—thank you—uses: at least they are not on the streets bothering other people. That is typical stereotyping of young unemployed people as muggers and robbers. I understand that Martin Ferguson was on radio this morning in fact continuing the stereotype of young Australians as people who are not keen to work. Do you know what he said? This is really embarrassing. This is one of your spokespeople. He said, `Are you trying to tell me that 1½ days or two days a week is going to give people the discipline to work?' And then he said—and here comes his real attitude: `Then they go home and go back to bed or watch TV for the rest of the week.' That is Martin Ferguson's view of the young unemployed—once they have had the opportunity to make a contribution to a community project they will just go back to bed and watch telly. That is what you think. You have no business asking a question on this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Heffernan, the government's approach to young unemployed includes trialling some schemes for work for the dole, giving people the opportunity to make a contribution to their community and to pick up some experience and some confidence—in a sense, to give something back for the unemployment benefits that they get. What Labor wants to concentrate on today, this nitpicking exercise of opposing everything the government does when they failed so abysmally themselves, is just a part of a much broader package. The package includes higher economic growth, lower interest rates, a balanced budget—something that with even the best abacus in the world they could never achieve—encouraging small business and, very importantly, revitalising apprenticeships and traineeships, providing more entry level training places.

We believe that work for the dole will assist young people with a work ethic. It will give them an experience of work. It will promote the culture of work and, more importantly, it will do something to attack the cycle of despondency and despair that is in the young unemployed around Australia who are sadly there because of Labor's incompetence.

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

In a time of low inflation, the purchasing power for any goods and services that are needed by pensioners is not therefore going to be seriously affected because of the maintenance of the value of the pension. ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections on my left.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the illumination of the minister, it was actually reported on Tuesday, 4 February in the Examiner , a paper, I understand, that is Launceston based. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —There are consequences to any action. I would point out to the Senate that the consequences for this government of having—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—This government inherited a massive budget deficit. The consequences of dealing responsibly with that are that we have had to make decisions which in fact have meant savings to the national accounts. We have done that because it is the responsible thing to do and because we were elected to do just that. The people of Australia were sick and tired of having their national accounts running in debt.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. The supplementary question went to a statement—an allegation—by Mr McKay, the Tasmanian Minister for Community Services. Senator Newman was asked if Mr McKay was right in what he said. I ask you to direct her to answer the supplementary question.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. I refer to the proposed compulsory work for the dole scheme in rural and regional areas that the Prime Minister announced yesterday after claiming that he had examined how such a scheme might work over a few weeks. Minister, what evidence do you have that young people need to be compelled to work, that they do not have a work ethic and that they are somehow refusing job opportunities? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stott Despoja, some of your questions are in fact a delight. I note that some notes from the Democrat party room have been released this morning. I take it as welcome acknowledgment—albeit, you could not actually bring yourselves to say it—that you just might support at least this: a voluntary work for the dole scheme. As I read the second paragraph of the notes that you have been so gracious as to release, it says that all Democrat senators confirm their strong opposition to schemes which rely on compulsion. It follows, therefore, that there might be some things we need to talk to you about, but you might have some sympathy with some voluntary aspects to schemes.

BREAK.PARA: It is unfortunate to have such despondency and despair in young Australians who perhaps have not yet had a chance of having a job. That is the reason for the focus on young people—not because they are particularly seen in any negative light whatsoever. I certainly hope you won't go tittle-tattling around that that is our view, because it certainly is not our view.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tittle-tattling?

—I say that, Senator Bourne, because Senator Stott Despoja has a tendency to do a little bit of tittle-tattling around. If she is not brought back into line, she might head out and do it. Now she asks me—

—Oh, you are very sweet when you are excited, Senator Woodley! Senator Stott Despoja asked me a very serious question, and that is what are we doing for the rest of the unemployed population. That is a serious question.

BREAK.PARA: I will not bother repeating for the third time today the deplorable state of unemployment that was left by the government that do not realise why they were rejected—and that is the Labor Party—that still have not apologised to the electorate; that still maintain they were on the right track; and that still believe the electorate made a mistake. Senator Stott Despoja, you would know well the deplorable state of unemployment left in Australia after 13 years of Labor. No policy you could drum up would do more to get people employed than that and put more money in people's pockets. We want a balanced budget. We are encouraging small business; revitalising apprenticeships and traineeships; and drastically and creatively revitalising assistance to unemployed Australians, with 90 per cent of the money towards that going to the long-term unemployed left to us by Labor.

So this government clearly recognises the problems of unemployed Australians, especially the long-term unemployed. There is no one simple fix. I think the work for the dole schemes that we will be piloting, along with all the other things that we wish to do to tackle this problem, are a worthwhile exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer, but I would like her to clarify something. Firstly, is this work for the dole scheme for 16‐ to 20‐year‐olds only? No tittle‐tattle; just yes or no. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

—I think they would do better to protest to their own government. I make the point again: this ship is travelling far from Australian shores—nowhere near the shores.
—You are wrong.
—You are wrong!
—Senator Brown thinks he is always right. In this instance, I think he will find that he is wrong. If it is far from Australian shores, then he need not be concerned in the way that he is.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, do you recall your election policy document Better communications and the statement in that document that:

QUESTION.PARA: The days when digital communications could be regarded as a premium service have passed.

Now that your expert committee for the review of the standard telephone service has completed its report to you, how do you propose to ensure that those days have indeed passed and that digital communications will now become a reality for all Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I think all Australians would recognise that the digital revolution is very much under way. In this country, it will be very important to ensure that people around the nation—not just in the capital cities—do have access to the latest technologies. It is quite clear that we are moving rapidly in the digital direction. Something like 77 per cent of exchanges are now digitised. We made a promise, which Labor was never prepared to make, to ensure that 93.4 per cent of Australians had access to ISDN capable exchanges by July of this year. All we got from the Labor Party was rubbishing by Michael Lee, who somehow thought that this was going to cost about $14 billion. The fact is that it was eminently affordable.

ANSWER.PARA: The important thing in addressing the standard telephone service for the first time ever—and that is what we did when we conducted a high level review—was to look at the possibilities of raising the standard. You can do that in a variety of ways. You can do it by raising the quality of service people have, particularly in rural and remote areas; you can do it by improving technologies. We take the view that you should not be technology specific. Indeed, Labor, time and again, made mistakes by being technology specific—whether it was a commitment to phase out analog mobile telephones or whether it was a requirement that satellite pay television had to be transmitted by digital format.

The committee, which reported to me last week, has provided a number of very useful recommendations. All of those will be taken into account by the government in determining its approach on this important issue. There were something like 16 recommendations covering areas such as pay phones, connection times, quality of service, national access to digital data services, community access points, services to Aboriginal communities and services to those with disabilities. Perhaps Senator Schacht has only read the odd press release and has not yet had time to read the 200 pages of the report, but the fact is that there are a lot of very valuable recommendations in there—a number of which the government will be addressing very seriously.

BREAK.PARA: The members of the group, I think, have done us a great service. They have provided a mine of useful information. They have addressed the difficult issue of national digital data capability and made some recommendations that, if we do not have a substantial uptake in service on the part of consumers by, I think, July of next year, we ought to look at mandating the requirement for all services to be digital by 1 January of the year 2000. That obviously has cost implications, and quite clearly it would not be responsible of us to simply endorse that without conducting a proper examination of the costs of providing those services.

But we have made it very plain in our policy approach, in marked contrast to that of Labor, that we do want a clever country outside the metropolitan areas, that we do want to see digital data capability available wherever possible and affordable—
Senator Carr interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You say that, but you would not have the slightest idea. There are some very interesting survey findings contained in the report, particularly in trying to ascertain the level of unmet demand. It would seem to date that the remarkably fast take‐up of services like the Internet and, indeed, pay television may reflect the fact that you get the easiest ones first. It does not necessarily follow that the balance of the population do want access to digital services or have any intention of subscribing to the Internet. So we have to be very careful before we simply impose costs which may well flow back into higher local call charges, higher exchange charges, higher telephone rental charges.

BREAK.PARA: But against that background, let me simply say that the members of the committee have done us a great service, and I will be studying their report very carefully before we make any final decisions on the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, do you agree with Professor Henry Ergas's assessment that the majority report of the committee is `poorly focused, at times clearly illogical and generally inadequate'? He was a member of the committee with a minority report. Are you aware of the turmoil which your press release last Friday, at the time of the release of the report, has caused throughout the communications industry and of the condemnation of your handling of the report by members of the committee? For example, are you aware that the Managing Director of ATUG, Mr Alan Horsley, said, `You risk losing the confidence of the industry if you ignore the substantial body of work undertaken over a reasonable period of time'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact is that we are not ignoring the community, the industry or, indeed, the members of the committee. Their report does provide some very valuable recommendations. I do not endorse any suggestion that the majority report was inadequate or lacking in focus. All I did was to say that Professor Ergas had raised the very important issue of costing. Indeed, the majority report does not put a figure on the level of costs that might be required. The terms of reference did ask that those matters be addressed in detail and, therefore, it is a matter for us to ensure that we understand the full cost implications before adopting those recommendations.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, I say once again that the majority report is a very valuable input into a very difficult issue. It is not simply a matter of picking out digital data capability; it is a matter of addressing all of those 16 recommendations. Very many of them, I would have thought, should have bipartisan support, and I hope that you will get around to reading the report in due course. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, one of the key election commitments of the Howard-Fischer government, the family tax initiative, was delivered in full on 1 January 1997. Is it a fact that on 2 January this year nearly 900,000 Australian families directly benefited from the family tax payment? What has been the reaction of organisations that deal with families on a day-to-day basis to how the family tax initiative is actually assisting families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —It is pretty clear that on this side of the parliament there is real concern for what has happened to Australia's families over the last 13 years. So it is appropriate that, when something good happens to Australia's families, we should make it very clear as to how and why it has happened. That is, at the last election, Madam President, as you would know, we went to the Australian people promising to look after Australian families better. Many thousands of those families went backwards under Labor rule. I point out to you, Madam President, that NATSEM put out a report just last December stating:

ANSWER.PARA: Putting together the divergent trends in market income, cash transfers and income taxes, [between 1982 and 1993] the average Australian's household experienced a real decline in disposable income of $38 a week.

That is, a decline of $38 a week between 1982 and 1993 happened to Australia's households. So we promised a turnaround partly by introducing the family tax initiative, and we have done a lot of other things as well, Madam President, as you know.

From 2 January, as Senator Macdonald has said, we delivered that promise in full. The implementation of the family tax initiative has gone very smoothly. On the first payday, nearly 900,000 low to middle income Australian families with dependent children received a payment under part A. Of these, nearly 400,000 also received the increased benefits under part B. So already, 900,000 battling families have received extra help to recognise the costs involved in raising children. One million more families will be claiming benefits through the tax system over the coming months.

Not only have Australia's families welcomed the family tax initiative but so have many community organisations. The National Council for the Single Mother and her Child has welcomed FTI, applauding the fact that sole parents are some of the biggest beneficiaries and that FTI minimises poverty traps and takes away some of the ammunition for sole parent bashing. ACOSS have said:

While we would still have preferred a payment more closely linked to the social security system, ACOSS regards the family tax initiative as a very positive step for low income families with children and thanks the government for its efforts.
The Brotherhood of St Lawrence have said:

. . . there is no doubting the value of this payment to low income families. It is the largest increase since the late 1980's increases in rent assistance and family payments and will lift some basic incomes by around 5% per cent of the poverty line.

With the smooth introduction of the family tax initiative, we will not be resting on our laurels. An ongoing campaign is to be conducted to ensure all bodies are aware of the FTI, including accountants, ethnic groups and groups in remote areas.

Madam President, with such an overwhelmingly successful introduction, it is unfortunate to have to report just one sour note, and I think we are getting a bit of a taste of it by the interjections from those on the other side. The doom merchants opposite do not like to see something successful happening for Australia's families. I draw your attention to the member for Werriwa, who decided that he would like to get post‐Christmas publicity, despite the fact that he was getting it at the expense of scaring Australia's families, who were looking forward to the benefits of the FTI in the new year.

But his grumblings were simply a one‐day wonder and battling Australian families are now well aware of the benefit which this has meant to them and their pockets after 13 years of being alternately ignored and put down, forgotten and damaged financially. The inheritance of the Labor years is well known to Australia's families and they voted those opposite out at the last election. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Earlier in question time your colleague Senator Vanstone said that it was well understood by all members of the cabinet employment committee for some time that the Prime Minister was going to announce a work for the dole scheme yesterday. Are we correct in assuming then that the formal processes of departmental consultation would have been carried out before this announcement was made? Was, for example, the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet consulted? If so, what was that department's view of the likely effectiveness of the scheme?
—If that department had a view, it would be the view of the department and the government's and not something that I would give to your benefit in here, Senator Faulkner.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question, Madam President. That is an absolutely unsatisfactory answer from Senator Hill. Senator Hill, if you do not know the answer to my questions, could you please establish quickly what they are and report back to the Senate. This government does have a very tarnished record now in terms of its commitment to transparency and proper process in government. I ask you to establish quickly what the answer to my question is and come back and advise the Senate.

—I think Senator Faulkner is intending to create a precedent here. I do not recall his government ever coming into the Senate and helping us with internal communications between ministers and their departments or between cabinet or cabinet subcommittees and their departments. I am not actually on that subcommittee of cabinet, but if it is of any benefit to you, Senator Faulkner, I understand that the Secretary to PM&C actually attends the meetings of the employment committee of cabinet, so presumably his department is very well informed.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, can you confirm that a United States military vessel, the Kilauea , involved in Operation Tandem Thrust, has made a serious miscalculation and run short of fuel and has been forced to stop near Magnetic Island, off Townsville, for refuelling? Is it not correct that this vessel is carrying large quantities of live ammunition and that this is having to be removed by flying it over Townsville before refuelling can commence? Is it a fact that refuelling at sea does pose a threat to the Great Barrier Reef? Are you concerned that if there is a spill, the boom nets that will be needed—the ones of the Queensland pollution control team—only have a maximum capacity to soak up 10,000 litres of fuel, while this vessel has a capacity of one million litres?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be very surprised if the US warship or its operators have made such a serious mistake in calculating their fuel. I do not think that is the usual way in which the US Navy operates. Beyond that, we understood there was the possibility of some refuelling taking place in association with Operation Tandem Thrust and that had been taken into account in the plans of GBRMPA in relation to their responsibilities. Certainly, there has been significant meaningful communication between the defence forces and GBRMPA in relation to the various environmental matters that are obviously relevant to this military operation.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the last part of your question, I am not sure what the capacity of the sweeping equipment is, but it seems beyond imagination that the whole tank of fuel of the ship would be lost in an accident. I would say that you are just slightly exaggerating to help your political point, Senator.

The US Navy and others associated with this exercise understand the importance and fragility of that particular environment. We have been assured, and I am confident, that they will operate in a way that respects that environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, surely if the US Navy cannot make Townsville on its way to the exercise and it did get the calculations so wrong that it has been limping towards Magnetic Island for the last couple of days, what confidence can you have in the many other calculations they will have to be making during the couple of weeks of Operation Tandem Thrust and they will have the environment as a high priority—they will have the environment up there as one of the key issues that they have to be concerned about during this operation?
—Get out of that!

—I will do my best. I do not accept the assertion that this ship has been limping around North Queensland waters. You can buy the line if you like, but I can assure you, as I said, that there have been extensive consultations between the defence forces and GBRMPA and others who are involved and responsible for ensuring the protection of our environment in that area. It is an area that has, in part, been set aside for defence force operations, as you know. Perhaps the size of this operation is larger than most, but certainly the authorities are very familiar with naval and other defence force operations in the area, and the environmental record has been good. As I said, the undertakings that have been given to me following the consultations give me reason for confidence.

—I address my question to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, can you assure the Senate that Korea Zinc will be required to meet the same environmental standards at its Townsville refinery as those required by the Labor government of Pasminco for its refinery in Tasmania? Is Pasminco wrong in maintaining that the approach being contemplated for the Townsville refinery falls far short of best practice?

—Those two companies are rivals and it is not therefore surprising that there is a little bit of sparring from time to time, each trying to press government to apply higher standards to the other. As the honourable senator would know, these two operations involve different chemical processes and therefore different environmental safeguards are appropriate. We are satisfied with the arrangement for Pasminco in the future. I would have thought that Senator Reynolds would blush just a little when she comes in here and stands by Pasminco's environmental record, in relation to sea dumping, as the justification for the question she now asks.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, is it true that Pasminco invested in alternative technology to meet the Labor government's deadline for ceasing the ocean disposal of jarosite? Will you assure the Senate that your government will require Korea Zinc to invest in similar technology to meet high environmental standards for the Townsville refinery?

—No, no. You have missed the point. It is a different process. There is no sea dumping going to be associated with the Korea Zinc refinery in Townsville. Ultimately, the waste will be shipped back to Korea, where it will go through a new process—which is, in turn, in the process of being evolved at the moment—which will meet the highest standards of environmental disposal. The waste from that process, as I understand it, will be completely inert. So it is probably better than you realise, Senator Reynolds. You will no doubt go back to Townsville and say, `That's good news for Townsville and this Howard government's doing the right thing by the environment.'

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. An ATSIC commissioned report launched last week found that the failure of governments to adequately implement the recommendations of the royal commission into deaths in custody represented a lost opportunity to reduce the unnecessary number of indigenous people in prisons. The Labor government spent $400 million implementing the recommendation of the royal commission, yet the rate of deaths of Aboriginal people in custody has actually increased. Minister, can you outline what this government is doing to address the problem and what steps are being taken to avoid more failure in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure Senator Schacht would be interested in this answer, as he is continually calling out across the chamber, but I notice that he is leaving. He is one of the constant interjectors and he was one who was part of the government that had all this inaction during the time that they were there.

ANSWER.PARA: The high rate of deaths in custody should interest everybody in the Senate chamber, including the opposition. But they are laughing on the other side. You can see the spokesman on the other side laughing while I am giving the answer to this question. I think that is how it has been regarded by them. It is a very serious issue that has been given urgent priority by the government.

BREAK.PARA: As we know, the Labor government spent more than $400 million implementing the recommendations of the commission. As the report shows—
Senator Forshaw interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Forshaw, you should also listen. The report showed that there has been little to show, with the deaths in custody continuing to rise. The report which I helped launch on Friday states that the level of Aboriginal overrepresentation in prison has not fallen at all over the nine years since the royal commissioner was appointed, nor over the 5½ years since it presented its recommendations. What an indictment. Levels of Aboriginal overrepresentation in prison have increased over that time and the levels in police custody have remained roughly constant.

BREAK.PARA: We cannot ignore the problem. We cannot simply throw more money at it and hope that it will go away. It is time to take some decisive action with clearly defined outcomes in mind. Since we gained government, we embarked on a program to address these high incarceration rates and deaths in custody. One of the first steps was to try to improve the standards of legal representation for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and a compliance audit of Aboriginal legal services was conducted. This action was taken in response to allegations that Aboriginal people were often overrepresented in prison due to a lack of adequate legal representation.

The government's recent appointment of police inspector Colin Dillon as an ATSIC commissioner has also put deaths in custody and high incarceration rates at the top of the agenda. Inspector Dillon has had more than 31 years in the police force, most recently in charge of Queensland's cross‐cultural advisory service. He has had extensive experience on the issues concerning Aboriginal people and the legal system.

Over the last three months, a series of meetings has occurred to organise a ministerial summit and an indigenous summit to address deaths in custody. The indigenous summit is scheduled for next Monday and Tuesday, 17 and 18 February. This indigenous summit will develop recommendations to be taken to the ministerial summit on 1 and 2 May. Representatives will attend. This meeting will focus on the issues of juvenile justice, diversionary strategies in policing and coronial inquiries in prisons.

Underlying issues will also be discussed. Commonwealth, state and territory ministers for indigenous affairs, law and justice, policing and corrective services have been invited to attend. The aim of the ministerial summit is to endorse a coordinated strategy which will bring together the Commonwealth, states, territories and indigenous groups in a consolidated effort to reduce high incarceration rates and, consequently, deaths in custody. It is imperative that the summits do not become ineffective talkfests. We must focus on outcomes and we are committed to producing results. I do not doubt the sincerity of previous efforts, but their failure makes it vital that we change our approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

I am sure that it is important that all members of the opposition are present when I state what the correct situation is. I referred to Professor Gregory's report on nursing homes and the lack of capital funding that was available under the previous government.

ANSWER.PARA: Professor Gregory in fact referred to the 1988 introduction of a new funding formula by the Labor government and the 1991 budget decision by the Labor government to halve the level of costs provided for upgrading a nursing home. He estimated at that time that the upgrading of existing stock of nursing homes may cost as much as $520 million alone. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I can add a little to the answer I gave Senator Brown in relation to the UK registered ship Pacific Teale . The information I have is that we did receive formal advice about the shipment from France to Japan by the UK registered ship Pacific Teale . The route the ship will take, according to this briefing note, will be around the Cape of Good Hope, then south of Australia, through the south-west Pacific and up to Japan, which seems to be consistent with what I recollected.

ANSWER.PARA: The government has received assurances from the Japanese, French and British governments that the radiological protection and safety arrangements meet international standards for such shipments. We have confidence in these international standards and are, therefore, satisfied with the radiological protection and safety arrangements for this shipment. We have also been given assurances by the Japanese, French and British governments that the planned route will not entail passage through Australia's territorial waters.

As a matter of interest, in the 35 years of existence of the IAEA's transport regulations, no accident has occurred during the transportation of radioactive material which has had any significant radiological consequences for people or the environment. Senator Brown can now confidently go back to his constituents and say that this shipment is being handled responsibly and in particular that there is no Australian interests threatened by it.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (FURTHER BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1996

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 December during the consideration of the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Further Budget and Other Measures) Bill, Senator West asked me how many disability support pensioners there are over the eligible age for the receipt of aged pension and I agreed to take the question on notice. I can now provide an answer to Senator West. I seek leave to have that answer incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

BREAK.PARA: There are approximately 3,170 disability support pensioners who are currently of age pension age, ie. 65 years for males and 60.5 years for females.
Disability support pensioners are normally transferred automatically to age pension on reaching the requisite age.

From 1 July 1997, the maximum rate of rent assistance payable to a single person in shared accommodation will be two‐thirds of the maximum rate of rent assistance payable to a single person living alone. (sgd) Senator Jocelyn Newman
10 February 1997

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), to questions without notice asked by Senator Faulkner and Senator Stott Despoja today, relating to a proposed `work‐for‐the‐dole' scheme for the unemployed.

This Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has had his job for less than a year and in that period 12,000 more young Australians have lost theirs. What has he promised them? He has promised them a measure which will create no real jobs. He promises them a measure which may create some 500 part-time sham jobs. For every 12 young Australians who have lost a job whilst this Prime Minister has been in government, he will offer them one half of a sham job greeting and meeting people at airports. What a con!

This is a government that just a few months ago ripped $1.8 billion out of employment assistance particularly for young Australians—training and employment. What does he offer them in return? Less than $5 million or $6 million—if it is going to cost that. For every $300 million the government has ripped out of the system in this budget during this financial year, it might put in an extra $1 million.

This is nothing more than a cynical, manipulative, unworkable, poll-driven con job introduced by this government. It follows another one. It follows the Green Corps that was announced just a few weeks ago, a con job which will provide $13 million a year for a program which under the previous government was provided some $90 million a year.

There is one clear message to Australia's youth out of the Prime Minister's statement yesterday. It is a message of despair. It is a message that says, `Do not expect real jobs under this government. Your future is of no core concern of this government and wherever you look—education or training—we have cut back on government spending.' It is a message that says to young Australians, `There will be less life opportunities under the Howard government.'

This message is born out of failure. You are doing this because you know that your economic strategy is not working; it is faltering. Growth is down, real jobs growth is down and unemployment is up. The engine room of this economy has been stalled by your deliberate economic policies. What do you do? Recognising that unemployment will increase and continue to increase, you embark upon a con job. You are doing this because of what your budget has done to consumer confidence and consumer activity in our economy. One only has to look at the retail sector to get in indication of where young people are not finding jobs these days.

This is a tired old prescription for the conservative government, one that stifles the economy and one that tries to con the people with peanuts. This is a government which is floundering, as this policy shows. It came into government with one policy and buckets of prejudice. Its one policy idea was to dump all of our policies and its prejudice has been to blame the victim, to reactivate those reactionary sentiments that are drawn out through public opinion polls. If all else fails, it has another idea. If its one idea of dismantling our policies does not work, it will go back to Fightback. That is what it has done again.

Let us look at the history of this government, because there is a degree of misinformation, particularly from this minister. Last time John Howard was in government, he left 158,000 young Australians unemployed. That was in March 1983. When he came into government in March 1996, that figure was down to 87,000. In some 10 short months it has gone up from 87,000 to 99,000. He is back to his old habits—a 14 per cent increase in youth unemployment in less than a year.

What does he offer the unemployed in return? He offers them sham jobs, meeting and greeting people at airports, without adequate training. He has dismantled the well-thought‐out programs providing skill training and work opportunities, and he has ripped $1.8 billion out of an important part of government responsibility in this area—bad on policy; bad on process.

He obviously has no confidence in his Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone). He has no confidence in the department's views. He has replaced them with the views of his pollsters. This program is so badly thought out, so badly designed and so badly engi neered that we know that the minister and her department were against it and we know that the minister was not consulted in the end. She is marginalised as a wet in this government, and there is absolutely no way that she would be treated in this disrespectful way if she were a member of the dry faction. My advice to this minister is, if you want to get your voice heard on behalf of unemployed Australians, put yourself on the list of the focus groups that Mr Robb polls every week. At least that way you might get your input to the Prime Minister.

Mr Fitzgerald from ACOSS has described this as a scheme that has failed in the past, is costly to administer and is not linked to recognised training. It is insulting to the unemployed that, having cut $1.5 billion from developed training programs, this government has now come up with a third-rate policy. This comes on top of cutbacks to uni fees and cutbacks to government school fees and increases in HECS. You have failed. You have tossed in the towel on unemployment and you have replaced it with a sham little project. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to take note of Senator Vanstone's answers to the questions directed to her regarding the work for the dole scheme.
—Why do you think Bob Carr thinks it's worth looking at?

—I will come to that, Senator, but what I want to do is address the failure of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) to advance any reasons for the decision announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to introduce the work for the dole scheme. The coalition parties went to the last election assuring people that they were not going to introduce such a scheme. Mr Kemp, the then shadow minister, put out a very indignant press release on 31 August 1995 saying that Labor was lying when it suggested that the coalition might introduce a compulsory work for the dole scheme. I think Mr Crean's claims have been vindicated by the Prime Minister's announcement the other day.

SPEECH.PARA: This is nothing more than a diversion. There was no attempt by the minister today to advance a claim that the work for the dole scheme would create one extra real job. There is no pretence from this minister that there are any real jobs to be created by this scheme. She concentrated only on the argument that it gave the unemployed an opportunity to give something back. That takes us back to Fightback and the blame‐the‐victim philosophy of the Liberal Party—one which they pretended to abandon at the last election because they knew it was unacceptable to the Australian public. Again, this proposal is about blaming the victim; it is not about creating any jobs.

If there were any real attempt to create permanent, lasting jobs with this scheme, you would get more support from the Australian community. The minister had two or three opportunities to answer questions about this issue today, and she did not attempt at any stage to justify the work for the dole scheme as being a job creation scheme, because it is not. It is a diversionary tactic. It has taken some of the other issues that are plaguing the government off the front pages. We are going to have the old hoary chestnut debate about the work for the dole scheme—the one we have every two or three years. No-one pretends it is going to do anything about helping long-term unemployed people get real jobs.

What really riles me most is the hypocrisy of the minister on this issue. When we took her through the cuts to Working Nation during the estimates process, she put up a very plausible case that she really was a caring minister and that she was just trying to finetune Working Nation and she was genuinely concerned about the long-term unemployed. PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect, 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This Act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that only one group have been excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) where such group has performed honourable overseas `active service'. That group being members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 which were excluded under `Operational Service' at Section 6. (1)(e)(ii) of the Act.

The various claims made in Statements to the House and the Senate and the contents of correspondence from various Ministers to maintain the exclusion are answered as follows, the answers are from documents obtained under FIO and from public record:

(i) `They were never allotted for operational service', (contained in a letter from the Hon. Con Sciacca Minister for Defence Science and Personnel 1995). A letter from the Secretary Department of the Navy to Treasury dated 11 November 1955 stated `the date that the Navy were allotted for operational service was 1 July 1955'.

(ii) `Members of the RAN were only doing the duty for which they had enlisted', (October 1956 The Hon. Dr Cameron representing the Minister for Repatriation in the Senate). This applies to all Service personnel everywhere.

(iii) `They were in no danger', (November 1956 The Hon. Dr Cameron representing the Minister for Repatriation in the Senate). They shared the same danger as all other Australian Service personnel serving in Malaya at the time.

(iv) `They were not on Special Overseas Service', (in a letter from the office of The Hon. Bronwyn Bishop Minister for Defence Industry Science and Personnel to Mrs Williams of Adelaide dated October 1996). Requirement for Special Overseas Service was introduced in 1962 without retrospective conditions, therefore has no relevance to events of 1960.

(v) `They were not on Active Service', (in a letter from the office of The Hon. Bronwyn Bishop Minister for Defence Industry Science and Personnel dated October 1996). It is now, as it was then, that Service Personnel had to comply with one of three requirements for Active Service, this group complied with two, or twice as many as is needed. The one that they did not comply with was, `is in military occupation of a foreign country'.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate should remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act, thereby giving the Australian sailors involved comparative recognition with the Army and RAAF personnel that served at the same time, and all other Australians who have served their Country on active service overseas.
