DEBATE.TITLE:
CUSTOMS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1996 IMPORT PROCESSING CHARGES BILL 1996
CUSTOMS DEPOT LICENSING CHARGES BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 February, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —Continuing from the point I reached when this matter was last debated, I want to move to the legislation arising from the Customs Depot Licensing Charges Bill 1966 and its effect upon some of the smaller bond stores, particularly those which operate in the state of Tasmania. Cities like Sydney and Melbourne have bond stores that have many transactions per day and a huge financial turnover in terms of the charges that they can levy. In relation to the small bond stores which exist in Tasmania, the overwhelming majority would have a very small number of transactions. In fact, some of those bond stores are furniture removalists. At the present time, those bond stores have the capacity to bring a citizen's furniture into the country from overseas and to hold any of that equipment in their bond stores whilst dealing with the customs requirement.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a major saving for inhabitants of an island state such as Tasmania. Without the facility of these sorts of small bond stores being available in the state, it could be that the removalist would have to bring the consignment in from overseas, separate that part which had to be lodged in a bond store when the consignment landed, say, in Melbourne, and either store the rest of the consignment there or bring it to Tasmania whilst awaiting the clearance from the bond store for that part of the transaction. This is the sort of advice that we are receiving from the small businesses within Tasmania currently able to operate small bond stores.I am advised that the legislation will cause the smaller bond stores to cease to participate. In other words, it will close the bond store operation because of the cost factor, which is not recoverable given the small number of transactions that is involved.

The legislation proposed for the lower differential charge recommended that a maximum number of transactions of 100 per year be allowed. On the advice that I have, that is not enough to keep the smaller bond stores open and operating. The Labor Party will be pursuing an amendment—as Senator Cook has advised—to increase the lower minimum to $500. That is more realistic, given the number of transactions that might occur.

There is another consequence for a state like Tasmania. If the effect of the legislation as proposed is the closure of the smaller bond stores, then it is possible that a state such as Tasmania would end up with no bond stores because no‐one was prepared to pay the charges. That would mean that an importer attempting to bring goods in from overseas would have to land them, say, in Melbourne or Sydney, have them cleared there and then have the transportation which had been interrupted for the bond store clearance continued to Tasmania. It is inevitable in those circumstances that there would be additional costs for those bond stores. That is a consequence that a state like Tasmania does not need and a consequence that small businesses in Tasmania do not need.

If this government is pursuing the interests of small business, then it will agree to the amendment that Labor proposes in this regard, particularly when you consider the piddling amount of income that the proposal as put by the government at this stage will raise in revenue. It could be—I would be interested to hear what Senator Parer has to say about this matter—that as little as $75,000 will be raised by this measure. If that is the case, what is the purpose of taking the risks that I have outlined? What is the purpose of imposing what are potentially significantly higher costs on the Tasmanian community and on small businesses in Tasmania for a revenue gain of about $75,000? But perhaps it would be more appropriate to deal with that matter when this legislation is in committee and the amendments are being considered.

I should say at this stage that it is estimated by some of the bond store operators who have contacted my staff that, if the measure is passed as proposed and it does have the effect of closing down bond stores, that will increase freighting costs, because of transport interruptions, by $10 to $15 per cubic metre. That is a concern which is real for the Tasmanian community because, as I said earlier, the cost impact of a measure such as this will have a significant impact on an economy which is not doing well at the moment, in which small businesses are not doing well at the moment. Tasmania least of all needs an interruption to trading businesses which could cost jobs, have additional costs for the community and raise a pittance in terms of the overall budget for the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I support what has just been said. Senator O'Brien has covered much of the territory I would have covered, and I will leave that on the record. I, too, have been contacted by Mike Watts and Beth Souter, who have the Celtic Southern Cross business importing Celtic music and instruments to Australia. They work out of Liffey, under the Great Western Tiers of Tasmania—one of the most spectacular and beautiful places in the country. The business address is via the little post office at Bracknell, as Senator O'Brien said. They are speaking up for thousands of other small businesses.

SPEECH.PARA: The import processing charge changes will have an extremely detrimental effect on a small number of marginal importing businesses, including speciality businesses like theirs—enough to put them out of business in some cases. In fact, by reducing the threshold for the import processing charge for a bundle of goods coming into the country from $1,000 to $250, some 29,000 lots of small bundles of imported goods coming into the country for small business will, in the main, be hit with a fee of $44.55.

It is pretty easy to see that if you are working on lots of $250 an almost 20 per cent impost through the import processing charge makes a very big difference to either your profitability or the sales you will have. It is these things that lead to life or death for small businesses. The government really should very seriously consider withdrawing this change.

I think there is a theory behind this that it will force some of the small business operators to use the computer based option—$22.80 for processing the same goods. But that is not the case. Many of these small businesses have, as part of their operational advantage, time on their hands to process matters like this manually and the ability to go from place to place to ensure that business is carried out. They do not have to do it through computers. If people want to do that, well and good. But the point is that this charge, one way or another, is going to catch these small businesses and leave them with fewer options.

For the reasons that have already been put forward by Senator Margetts, Senator O'Brien and others, I will be supporting the amendments to get rid of this increase in the processing charge and the other amendments that the ALP has mentioned, because they will selectively hit small business. They will selectively hit some very enterprising speciality businesses in Tasmania and doubtlessly in even bigger numbers elsewhere in the country.

They are going to bring in a piddling amount of money to the government but they are going to have a torpedo effect on a number of small businesses. That flies in the face of what everybody in this chamber stands for. The government ought to seriously consider dropping the provisions adverted to in this bill. I hope that if it does not the Senate will have the numbers to correct the bill for the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of customs bills introduces a cost recovery regime for import related services delivered by the Australian Customs Service. While increasing costs are never to be welcomed, the Australian Democrats believe this move is appropriate given the tight budgetary situation which has affected all departments and all sectors of government. Importers also will need to share part of the budgetary burden.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of these bills is to treble revenue collected from $20 million to $66 million. I think it is important to note, however, that the cost recovery regime does not cover activity associated with Customs community protection functions relating to the detection and interception of prohibited imports and drugs.

We are also pleased that the charges will not apply to the processing of export transactions. This is an appropriate motivational policy. Exempting exporters from the proposed user‐pays system recognises the importance of export industries in improving our trade balance and generating jobs. I also note it is a welcome change in the way this government has treated some of our exporters to date.

The Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) has announced that Customs has undertaken detailed costings of its services. This is an important safeguard to ensure that importers will not be excessively charged. We would urge the minister to ensure that regular costings of its services are undertaken in future.

The Australian Democrats did, however, have a number of concerns with the initial customs reform package, specifically in terms of how those reforms would have impacted on small business. We had these concerns despite only three small business approaches to us—one of which is the exceptionally active single Tasmanian who has been in contact with us and also, I gather from the remarks, with colleagues on either side.

We raised our concerns with the minister responsible for Customs, the Hon. Geoff Prosser, and his office and we acknowledge his and his department's cooperation in addressing them. We are pleased to see that the minister took our concerns and those of other members of the Senate on board and acted on them in good faith. In view of this, the Democrats will be supporting the bills before us.

Firstly, the Democrats are most pleased the government has agreed to delay a reduction of the import entry threshold for commercial importation through the post from $1,000 to $250 for 12 months. The 12‐month deferral will provide Customs with time to further develop and encourage use of the Internet for processing of imports. The Internet provides a great opportunity for maximising the efficiency of processing imports and we welcome this approach.

The minister has assured us that within 12 months he envisages an Internet based facility which will be available for the lodgment of Customs entries. This will provide a cost-effective solution for low volume importers, typically very small businesses, which do not need the full capability of the Customs COMPILE computer system. I expect the minister to keep his word.

The low cost and ease of use of the Internet will be a great boon to importers, offering an alternative to the need for lodging paper documents in person at customs houses and international mail centres. Moreover, the cost of electronic processing is around half the cost of manual processing, as set out in this bill.

We do, however, recognise that a number of small businesses will probably remain on manual systems. Their numbers and needs should be monitored—and I believe should be advised to the Senate if you have them available to you—to avoid unfairly burdening them as a result of this legislation.

In this light, I hope that the government will do what it can to ensure that Internet access remains affordable and equitable. I urge the minister responsible for Customs to pay close attention to this matter which is in the domain of the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston). If he does not, I can assure him that persons on the crossbenches will.

Internet access charges may well increase, especially if the option of untimed data calls for small business is removed. The government has foreshadowed this possibility and the Democrats, through my colleague Senator Lyn Allison, have already noted their concerns over this proposal. It is important that Internet access does not become a significant cost element to small business.

Secondly, the government has approved an amendment to the Customs Depot Licensing Charges Bill 1996, which introduces a two‐tier annual licence fee instead of the flat $4,000 annual fee which was initially pro posed. This amendment is of particular value to smaller depots, which are mostly located in smaller states or in regional centres. It means that smaller depots, specifically those which have less than 100 transactions a year, will be subject to a licence fee of only $1,500—a significant saving when compared to the $4,000 annual fee.

In conclusion, I would like to note that the Australian Democrats regret that the desired 1 January 1997 commencement date for charges had to be delayed until 1 April 1997 pending passage of these bills. Unfortunately, due to the amount of legislation before the Senate in the last session of parliament it was not possible to consider the initial package of bills as was hoped. However, the Democrats are pleased to see that the minister did not seek to introduce retrospective legislation but instead altered the commencement date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank all honourable senators for their contributions. I would just like to make a couple of points. Firstly, phasing the introduction of cost recovery over the next four years is a luxury that the budget imperative, as presented to us on taking over government, in our belief cannot allow. The whole thrust of the measures contained in this legislation is to align the cost of processing imports with that sector of the community—that is, the importers—which generates customs work rather than spreading the cost across all taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point is that the proposed system of two‐tier rates is supported but with a different definition of what is regarded as a small depot by the Labor opposition. The government proposes a transaction definition of less than 100 transactions in its amendments, but I understand that Senator Cook now proposes that this be raised to `less than 500'. Senator Cook noted that the amendments proposed by the government would result in 15 per cent of all depots—that is 415 in number—falling below the 100 transaction volume per annum.

More significantly, from historical data we see that this percentage is higher in the smaller states and territories. In the Northern Territory, 72 per cent of the current operators will incur the lower fee. In Tasmania, 60 per cent of current operators will incur the lower fee. In South Australia, 30 per cent of the current operators will incur the lower fee. In Queensland, 17 per cent of operators will incur the lower fee. The government considers that this amendment addresses regional Australian concerns and that it is not necessary to increase the small depot threshold as Senator Cook has foreshadowed.

With regard to the contributions of Senators Margetts and Brown, I would like to make the following points. The move from $100 to $250 at the post relates to commercial importations only, not to personal importations, which will remain at the higher level. The reason for deferral of 12 months, as has been pointed out by Senator Murray, is to coincide with Customs' development of Internet facilities, which will allow small business importers who use international mail facilities to lodge simplified entry information remotely. This will allow them to incur an electronic lodgment fee of only $22.80 instead of $44.55. Of course, facilities will still be available for fax lodgments.

It will more significantly reduce costs associated with travelling to an international mail exchange, lodging documents, awaiting clearance and collecting goods. When several hours of travelling time is involved, cost to business can be high. The move in the threshold to $250 addresses a longstanding anomaly, which I do not think too many people have picked up—I think Senator Murray has, probably in the briefings—between requirements for commercial importations through the post and those via air and sea carriers. The figure of $250 currently already applies. We are talking about only the post.

For importers using air couriers and express couriers, for instance, all commercial importations with a value of $250 or more have required a customs entry. This anomaly provides an unfair advantage for a business using the post as an alternative. In fact, it is an encouragement, as Senator Cook would appreciate.

The 12 months grace period signals to importers that the inequity is being addressed while at the same time providing importers that use international mail services time to adjust to the new costs and to examine the Internet options that will be available in 1998. In conclusion, I again thank senators for their contributions and signify my thanks to Senator Murray for the support of the Australian Democrats.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The government amendments to two of these bills, the Customs Depot Licensing Charges Bill and the Customs Amendment Bill (No. 2), have been circulated as requests. This further illustrates the confusion concerning the proper application of section 53 of the constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the Customs Depot Licensing Charges Bill, the amendments seem to have been presented as requests on the basis that it is a bill imposing taxation and is not amendable by the Senate, which is probably correct. The other bill, however, increases certain charges but is apparently not classified by the government drafters as a bill imposing taxation. The amendments have been presented as requests, however, because they reduce the scope of the charges levied by the bill but leave charges higher than the status quo.

As I have indicated in my previous statements, this type of amendment has never been regarded by the Senate as requiring a request as it clearly does not increase any proposed charge or burden on the people within the terms of the constitutional provision.

To use a shorthand expression, the amendment merely partly restores the status quo. Such an amendment will not be a request under the recommendations of either the Senate or House of Representatives committees which have examined this question. A statement made in the House of Representatives on 2 December 1996 indicated that the Senate's interpretation is now accepted in that house. The amendments to the Customs Amendment Bill (No. 2) will therefore be treated as amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, you will notice that there are other amendments relating to this section. I have just spoken to Senator Cook and he has agreed that, if the Senate agrees, I can move my amendments before his. If the Senate agrees to the amendment by the government to delay the commencement, it might be voted against later or be amended further. TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that item 12, as amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Margetts in opposing item 12. The Senate has just moved to delay the imposition of the new charge for 12 months, but that is simply giving the small number of small businesses affected 12 months grace. They have lobbied against the proposal for increased fees. They have given a cogent example of how some specialist businesses will be threatened by these fees, which are the equivalent of nearly 20 per cent of the total cost of items they are importing from overseas to put onto the Australian market and speciality items on which their livelihood depends.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot understand the Democrats turning down the submission that has come from those small businesses. Senator Murray has said that he hopes the government will review this further down the line and that it ought to be monitored if the government finds that these businesses are affected. Once you are out of business, it is a bit hard to review it, and monitoring does not bring a business back from bankruptcy.

I would have thought the other way around would be the way to do it. We ought to be supporting Senator Margetts and looking further down the line to see whether these businesses go across to the Internet or to the computer available option which is said to be so attractive so that effectively they extinguish the old system upon which they currently depend. That would have been the sensible thing to do. But, by tidying up a piece of legislation, we are effectively saying to those businesses, `You are in the way. We are going to give you 12 months. But when 12 months comes, you either submit or go out of business.' It is going to be as tough as that for some of them. It will certainly involve a great deal of inconvenience and increased costs.

Remember that these are marginal businesses. As Senator O'Brien has said, one of the businesses involved is looking at being able to pay for a position. This will make the difference between their being able to employ somebody or not. It may well make the difference between their staying in business or not.

As far as using the post is concerned, I would have thought the government would encourage that and would not see that as an impediment. I certainly did not think it would move to change an existing system to act as a disincentive to people using Australia Post. That does not make too much sense to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is overseas post.
—Well, overseas post. It goes in both directions.
—No, only imports.

—That is a point. But, whichever way it comes, yes, it is being imported from overseas. For those reasons, I support Senator Margetts's amendment very strongly. I think this change should be knocked out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is important to try to indicate the real level of concern here. Firstly, the reduction of the $1,000 threshold to $250, as the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer) has outlined, does in fact affect post in terms of equalising with air and sea and, secondly, also equalising it with courier charges, which are $250 already. The 12-month delay was one not to merely provide a delay but to provide the opportunity for new systems to be set up which would make the cost of transferring from manual to electronic processing, which is cheaper and more efficient, possible to bring into action. Of course, my quest for monitoring is to see that that does take place and does not result in those who remain on manual systems being appreciably disadvantaged.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats get approximately 11 per cent of the national vote. We get about 95 per cent of the national lobbying. We can always tell pretty well how big a measure is by the amount of correspondence we get. The Holsworthy issue runs now not just in thousands but in tens of thousands. I assure you, Minister, we have a very vigorous approach there.

On these issues, we have received one phone call and two letters from small businesses. Of those three, one was from someone in Tasmania, who seems to be a very active campaigner, one from WA and one from Adelaide. So, honestly, unless small business is asleep—and I am very close to small business—we have not had a high level of concern expressed to us. It may be a bigger issue in Tasmania than I envisage. There is nothing I have seen to date which justifies not accepting the government's amended positions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the opposition, I first of all indicate that, in the event that the Greens' amendment is defeated, I will move a further amendment in the name of the opposition which will ameliorate the impact of the change to the threshold. In the normal course, I would want my amendment to prevail. At this time, I am attracted to supporting the Greens' amendment in view of what has been said in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The point has been made that this refers to imports by post. The whole point of this amendment is, I think, that we are talking about small business. We are not just talking about the normal run of small business. Much of the information I have received has been information about what you would call micro business. These are one- or two-person operations, maybe a husband and wife operation, that operate in areas that might be, to the normal mind, somewhat arcane. But, nonetheless, they have carved out a niche business, almost a cottage industry, for themselves to support themselves and would obviously resort to the postal service.

Whether they have a personal computer, whether they can get onto the Internet and whether they can do all the other things are secondary matters. This is a sort of Australian self-reliance, independence initiative, that ought to be encouraged. It is not for every one; that is admitted and recognised. But what we are doing here is slapping big charges on people.

My preferred position is that obviously a service like Customs, which is an important service, has to have an element of cost recovery in it. It also has to have an element of service to the community. I would have thought the government is very concerned about lifting the level of Australian exports and about trying to do something about the balance of payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is only on imports.
—Well, that is right, but we are talking here about a number of companies that have intermediate goods imported to make their final product so they can then export a complete product.
—That is a long bow.

—We are talking about those sorts of companies. That is not an unusual thing. I know a number of small businesses that cannot find goods to complete their final product in Australia because they are not made in this country. They import those from overseas but, nonetheless, come up with a final product which embodies the import but can then be re‐exported.

SPEECH.PARA: The point is that I have considerable sympathy for the Greens' position. I do not understand entirely the Democrats' position. Maybe I have not paid sufficient attention to the explanation. But, from what I have heard, I would say that, if the measure is how many protest letters you get, this sector of industry is not an outspoken sector. It is not a well organised sector; it is a very small almost cottage industry sector. These people are not necessarily able to keep across every development. They are not experts in writing submissions or protest letters. But that does not mean that their voice is not important, that their cause is not real and that their concerns ought not be paid attention to. We in the opposition will do that. As I say, I am attracted to voting for the Greens. I am not entirely sure whether I will, but I will wait on your explanation, Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond very quickly. One of the things that I think Senator Brown and Senator Margetts have not picked up on—although I think they recognised it; Senator Murray pointed it out—is that all we are talking about are goods that are imported into Australia by mail. There is currently an anomaly. The charges we are talking about already apply to sea cargo, air cargo and courier but not to mail.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the problems associated with that—and hence the idea of correcting the anomaly—is that it is very easy to have a whole series of split consignments coming through by post which come in under the threshold. Anecdotally, I can tell you from the discussions I have had with Customs—Customs is not my portfolio, but I have been briefed by Customs officers—that it is not unusual to find the same bundles in post, but just under the threshold level.

I would guess that, if Senator Margetts's amendment did go through, we would see a considerable growth in the number of these sorts of goods being imported. I think, Senator, that if you were in a little business of importing things you would jump on the bandwagon to make sure you did that. So you would bring it through by post at the higher threshold than already applies to all other forms of transportation of goods into this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, as the amount has not gone down yet, although in real terms it has gone down over time, it is a bit bizarre to suggest that some time after changing a measure you then not only do not increase it with inflation but also bring it down to a level which, in reality, obviously will benefit the slightly bigger players and may well be one of the reasons, as Senator Cook has suggested, why there is not a bigger brouhaha in relation to the organisations. The Small Business Association, for instance, would have members who were bigger—in fact, most of the members would be bigger—than the kinds of small businesses we are talking about who have almost nobody to look after their interests. Many will find out after the event. Even if they have 12 months to work out what will happen to them, it will be difficult.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not have the same odium that the minister has in relation to the post—why, somehow or other, it is bad that people should use the post. I think it is not such a bad thing. My problem, as I mentioned in the debate on the second reading, is largely to do with the fact that what we are beginning to introduce by way of this proposal is the user pays principle which could be thought of as a regressive charge because the smaller you are, the larger it is in proportion to what you are doing.

The same argument has been used in banking, and it has been considered to be unfair in banking. I do not think that charging regressive charges is the way we should be going. Perhaps much of its cost is related to the fact that people have to fill in a form stating that that is what they are doing. If it is coming in by post and there is no form to check as none has had to be filled out, as far as I can see there is not much cost to the customs department. Therefore, are we saving that much money when, in fact, there might not be a cost involved if people know that they are under the limit and do not have to fill out a form in the first place?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I answer that, even though it may pre-empt what you will say, Senator Brown. If what I say does not pre‐empt your remarks, you are welcome to get up and say a few words.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no odium about the post. People are entitled to bring goods in whenever they like. But there is a clear anomaly there. If you import something which is below the threshold into this country through the post, you do not pay; if you do it through any other form, you do.

Senator, what you are saying—which I find a little difficult to follow—is that, if people want to import goods into this country below a certain level, they should not have to pay customs duty, they should be able to avoid customs. I think that is what you are saying. I am not sure why, just because someone brings something in through the post as compared to any other form, they should not have to go through the processes they have to go through when bringing it in by air or sea or courier, as Senator Murray said.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond on two points. First of all, with split lots coming into the country, no matter what the level is set at, that will occur. It is marginal. Anecdotal evidence has been given to me that it is very marginal, and that the bulk of this issue we are looking at is for single lots being brought in by business people who depend upon those single lots of specialty items. That is the first issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The second issue is about post. If you are importing once a month to Bracknell, Dubbo or Tennant Creek a small package, an item upon which your business depends, I can assure you that using the post is much better than using a courier or ship transport. If you are anywhere near small business and have costed the options, you will know that using sea transport or couriers for lots in the order of $250 is prohibitive.

On both counts—on cost and on convenience—post is the option. It is efficient and it is specially designed to be able to transport, quickly and cheaply, small items; whereas the other forms of transport are especially designed for large items, particularly bulk items. There are exceptions to the rules, but that is the case.
I reiterate: this change will be injurious to a very select small group of businesses and may force them out of a component of their business which is efficient and cheap and upon which they depend.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, very quickly, can I just remind you that, irrespective of the mode of importation, the charge imposed by customs is no different; it is all the same. But there is—and I just repeat to you—that anomaly that exists. I believe that this is what it is all about; it is to correct that.

—I am aware of the time and the huge backlog of legislation that we have, so I will not delay the committee at all. The minister says that there will be a backlog, and the way that he will overcome it—
—It is not a backlog.

—There is an anomaly. But to remedy that, you are going to seriously affect the individual business, and that individual business has been mentioned on a number of occasions in this particular debate. Is it appropriate, is it fair, is it reasonable to amend one anomaly and create another problem?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that it is creating another problem. As I pointed out—I do not know whether you were here; I am unsure—we are talking about the commercial importations, that is all, not personal importations. Currently, as it stands, if someone imports goods by post, they are not subject to this charge which applies if they import those goods by air, sea or courier.

SPEECH.PARA: As I mentioned earlier in discussion—this is anecdotal, but given to me by Customs people—with the figure at $1,000, it is very simple for people to organise a whole series of split consignments. It is the sort of thing you do in a small business. It is legitimate; there is nothing wrong with it. They are not doing anything illegal. It is what you would do just to be prudent in your business, to save a few bucks. It has been explained to me by Customs that it is not unusual to see in the post a series of little packages all much the same but below the threshold. I will just mention that to you.

I suppose that it is not creating another problem. I do not think anyone, apart from Senator Margetts, disagrees with the concept of user pays in this particular instance. But you are getting one group of people picking a mode of transport which gives them advantages not available to people who use three other modes of transport. That is simply what it is about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, if I follow your argument, you are saying that, if the importer using the mail is able to bring in a quantity of goods below the threshold, that is legitimate, and if they cannot they pay the penalty. Perhaps the gentleman that I referred to in the second reading debate will be able to split his consignment into, say, half—we are talking about $400—and he will avoid it. But somebody who is importing a single item at the same value will not have that advantage.

SPEECH.PARA: Whether the small businesses can avoid the consequences of this bill will depend upon how divisible their load is, just as is the case now. You have only lowered the threshold, not changed the problem. All you are doing with this bill is saying, `We are applying the same consequence to importers irrespective of where they bring their goods in from.'

Is it not more likely to be the case that the use of the mail is required for low cost and not urgent items, whereas couriers and other transport methods are likely to be used for production components and more urgent, and perhaps even perishable, goods?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is not right because they would just use airmail through the post. As it stands now, you could have a whole series of things up to $900 if you wanted to. They can still split consignments, but it will lower the threshold.
—Perhaps the minister could clarify how much revenue the government is expecting to gain from this measure.
—It is one of those cases when I cannot give you an accurate prediction because we do not know what people are going to do in changing their importing habits. I do not know.

—Surely you have some sort of estimate of the number of businesses involved already. Surely there is a starting figure of what you estimate is the case now. Perhaps we can then extrapolate what this might balloon out to, which is not actually changing the situation but retaining the status quo.
—I will give you an historical figure, which is not awfully accurate, of transactions between $250 and $1,000. There are 29,000 of them per annum.

—Those are the kinds of figures I had too. That would indicate that the revenue, even at that level, on the back of an envelope, could be $700,000 a year. Surely that, in terms of revenue gained, is disproportionate to the impossible impact that could have on the number of small, tiny, micro businesses that might be put out of business by this particular action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —If you are going to be fair and equitable about this—and I think the direction we are taking is being fair and equitable—we have to lift the threshold across the board, whether it be air, sea or courier. Obviously, if you are looking at that, to put everyone on the same level, you are looking at a substantially higher figure than that. We are currently talking about 29,000 in that category through the post.

SPEECH.PARA: What I really cannot come to grips with you on is that we are correcting an anomaly that exists, which is available to anyone if they wanted to use it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay this too much longer. Obviously, the minister has a different definition of equitable than I have. For those people who believe that user pays, strictly adhered to, is equitable, I have a different opinion and I will have to agree to differ with the minister. There are many issues in Australia in terms of provision of services.

SPEECH.PARA: It does look as if there will be some more jobs for Customs. I think there are probably better things for Customs to be doing. There are lots of jobs I think Customs should be doing that perhaps do not involve looking for other areas where they are not currently having to be involved.

As I said, in my opinion `equitable' is something to do with fairness and reasonable costs. User pays in this sense and creating a cost, which you do when you actually have to have those entries checked when they did not have to be checked before, is not exactly equitable. It is creating a cost, creating a charge and then charging unfairly to the ability to pay, and that is not equitable. I think we will just have to agree to differ on what our definition of equitable is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I am of the same opinion. The business of anomaly is interesting because this government actively supports all sorts of anomalies. Let me give you an example. If a logger sees a beautiful rainforest tree, cuts it down and sends it to the woodchip mill, he pays less in royalties than if he sends it to a sawmill. On the face of it, there are clear incentives to trash it through the woodchip mill rather than to give it higher added value. The government does nothing about that although that argument has been put to it for years. So the anomaly argument is just cant.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have here is a small group of businesses which are aided by the current system. To tidy up the current system, this government is saying, `We'll knock out that option which gives sustenance to that handful of businesses.' All we are saying is we do not support that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Schedule 1, item 12, page 7 (lines 28 and 29), omit the item, substitute:
Repeal the subparagraph, substitute:

SPEECH.PARA: I will not boil my cabbages twice. I gave the arguments as to why I support this position when I was speaking to the Greens (WA) amendment. Those arguments still stand. I think this is a way of both addressing the user-pays principle as well as softening the blow on small business.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Cook, I wonder if you could clarify what amendment you just moved. I thought you were talking about locking together all these amendments on the phasing in period. Is that what you are suggesting?

—I was talking about that, but then I got the running sheet, which blew my little plan out of the water, unfortunately. Since I appear on the running sheet and we swapped around with the Greens (WA) to allow them to go first, out of order on the sheet—
—Is this No. 5?

What the opposition is trying to achieve here is a phasing in of charges. The charges we seek are phased in over four years in the same percentage increases. These amendments gradually phase in the cost recovery charges over a period of 4 years.

Secondly, the Government has agreed to defer reduction of the import entry threshold for commercial importations through the post from $1000 to $250 for 12 months. This will provide time for an Internet mechanism for processing of imports to be established. This will provide an alternative to the need for lodging paper documents in person and cost about half the price.

Most importantly, however, implementing immediate cost recovery as the Government has proposed, will provide funds which can be used as a source of revenue for off‐setting the costs of establishing Internet‐based processing over the next 12 months as promised. As noted, the Democrats believe such a system has tremendous potential and encourage the Government to develop it.

In the long run, Internet based charging is likely to be of benefit to the very importers the ALP is seeking to assist through a phased in approach to cost recovery. For this reason we feel the Govern ment should be permitted to proceed as they have planned.

PARA.EMPHASIS: House of Representatives reasons for disagreeing to Senate amendments (10) to (18), (20) to (28) and (31) to (36)

PROCTEXT.PARA: These amendments are consequential upon other amendments proposed by the Senate to ensure that no newly arrived resident's waiting periods will be introduced for carer pension, widow allowance, disability wage supplement, mature age allowance, special benefit, partner allowance, maternity allowance, child disability allowance, double orphan pension, mobility allowance, seniors health card and family payment above the minimum rate.

Subject to accepting the recommendations made by both the majority and minority reports of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee in its consideration of the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Resident's Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill 1996 that newly arrived resident's waiting periods should not apply for child disability allowance or double orphan pension, the House of Representatives remains of the view that newly arrived resident's waiting periods should be imposed for the other payments. Accordingly, the House of Representatives opposes the consequential amendments proposed by amendments (10), (11), (12), (13), (14) and (15).

The House of Representatives considers that these amendments—to not introduce newly arrived resident's waiting periods for carer pension, widow allowance, disability wage supplement, mature age allowance, special benefit, partner allowance, maternity allowance, parenting allowance, mobility allowance, seniors health card, more than the minimum rate of family payment and health care cards—should not proceed as they would counteract the electoral mandate given to the Government at the 1996 election to introduce its election commitment relating to imposing a two year newly arrived resident's waiting period on most welfare benefits. The House of Representatives notes that access of newly arrived migrants to Australian social security payments compares favourably with other western nations.

With respect to carer pension, it is noted that the Government had intended moving amendments in the Senate to take account of recommendation 3 of the majority report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee that special needs relatives be exempt from the carer pension newly arrived resident's waiting period, as well as exempting refugees, former refugees or a family member of the refugee or former refugee from that waiting period. The House of Representatives is of the view that those amendments should have prevailed.

The amendment proposed by the Senate in relation to widow allowance (Senate amendment (17)) would result in a disparity in access between widow allowance and newstart allowance despite the eligibility criteria for widow allowance having always essentially been aligned with those applying for newstart allowance. Previously, widow allowance has been subject to a 26 week residence requirement, akin to the 26 week newly arrived resident's waiting period for newstart allowance.

The House of Representatives considers that the introduction of a newly arrived resident's waiting period for disability wage supplement addresses concerns that in deciding to come to Australia, migrants should be aware of the need to provide adequately for themselves after they arrive in Australia so as not to make undue calls on the Australian taxpayer. The House of Representatives notes, however, that there has been a recognition, as reflected in the legislation, that circumstances sometimes change after a person arrives in Australia and that as a result, the newly arrived resident's waiting period will not apply to a person who first suffered a continuing inability to work in Australia because of an impairment or who becomes permanently blind while in Australia. Therefore, the House of Representatives does not consider that the Senate amendment relating to disability wage supplement (Senate amendment (18)) is warranted.

The House of Representatives believes that any failure to introduce a newly arrived resident's waiting period for special benefit will operate to effectively undermine the newly arrived resident's waiting periods that operate for other income support payments, such as newstart allowance. The Senate amendments relating to special benefit would allow many unemployed people to avoid the two year waiting period provisions, and therefore the House of Representatives does not consider that the Senate amendment relating to special benefit is warranted. Although the Government had proposed that a newly arrived resident's waiting period should apply for special benefit, the House of Representatives notes that the Government had and continues to recognise the importance of ensuring that there is an adequate safety net to take care of those persons who suffer substantial changes in their circumstances beyond their control.

To that end, the Bill as introduced and passed by the House of Representatives had provided that such persons would be exempt from the operation of a newly arrived resident's waiting period. Further, it is understood that the Government had indicated to the Senate that it proposed moving a number of concessionary amendments to the special benefit provisions to take on board those recommendations made by the majority report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee that impacted on special benefit.

With respect to partner allowance, the vast majority of those receiving partner allowance are spouses of recipients of newstart allowance. Prior to July 1995 the unemployed person would have received the partnered rate of unemployment payment and been excluded from this combined payment for 26 weeks. The House of Representatives understands that the amendments proposed by the Government in the Bill as introduced with respect to partner allowance are a further step in a process instigated by the former Government of ensuring that persons qualify for social security payments in their own right. The House of Representatives endorses this position and so opposes Senate amendment (26).

The House of Representatives disagrees with Senate amendment (28) relating to parenting allowance. Parenting allowance is an income support payment and as such, has always been aligned with other income support payments such as newstart allowance. It was introduced in July 1995 by the previous Government to make available a payment to those looking after children, to compensate for the abolition of the partnered rate of social security benefits. It is noted that for that reason, newly arrived resident waiting provisions mirroring those applicable to newstart allowance were inserted into the Social Security Act 1991 when parenting allowance was introduced by the former Government in July 1995.

The House of Representatives does not agree that there is a need for Senate amendments (32) or (36) on the basis that the operation of a newly arrived resident's waiting period for the seniors health card or health care cards would cause undue hardship. Persons subject to a newly arrived resident's waiting period would still have immediate access to Medicare. These concession cards provide access to Commonwealth and State/Territory concessions which newly arrived migrants should not expect to receive immediately upon entry to Australia.

The House of Representatives agrees with the position that had previously been adopted by the former Government that people should qualify for social security payments in their own right and notes that the former Government had introduced a number of initiatives to give effect to that policy.

Accordingly, the House of Representatives does not agree with amendments (20), (23) and (34) that would seek for newstart allowance, sickness allowance and youth training allowance, respectively, to maintain the exemption from the operation of a newly arrived resident's waiting period that currently applies to a person who is a member of a couple immediately before entering Australia and whose partner has been an Australian resident for at least 26 weeks.

In any event, the House of Representatives considers that it would be inappropriate, in the light of the newly arrived resident's waiting period being extended to 104 weeks, to continue to require only that a newly arrived migrant's partner who has been an Australian resident for 26 weeks before the newly arrived migrant could claim an exemption from the operation of a newly arrived resident's waiting period. Such a disparity would not be justifiable on policy grounds, in view of the individual entitlement to social security payments and will result in complexity in administration.

The House of Representatives notes that these amendments would result in a 104 week newly arrived resident's waiting period for newstart allowance, sickness allowance and youth training allowance only applying to persons who either enter Australia or are granted a permanent visa after Royal Assent has been given to the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Resident's Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill 1996. The 26 week newly arrived resident's waiting period would apply to those persons who had entered Australia and been granted a permanent visa before that day. The House of Representatives further notes that the amendments are being proposed in response to suggestions that the legislation is retrospective.
The House of Representatives does not agree that the legislation is retrospective.

The House of Representatives accepts that there was wide coverage in Australia of the Government's policy announcement relating to newly arrived resident's waiting periods, both during the 1996 election campaign and about the date from which it was proposed that the extended waiting period should apply, that is, 1 April 1996. Further, the House of Representatives understands that information foreshadowing the Government's new policy was provided to the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs by the Department of Social Security. This was distributed to overseas posts on 19 March 1996 to provide to all visa applicants and to successful visa applicants when a visa is issued; to migration applicants who had already received a visa but had not arrived in Australia on 21 March 1996; and on 27 March 1996 to all assurers of support of applicants who had not yet arrived in Australia. Since 1 April 1996, this information has been provided to all on‐shore migration applicants and any nominators or assurers.
The majority report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee did not consider that the legislation was retrospective. The majority report noted:

"The Committee notes concerns about the retrospective provisions in the Bill and evidence that these may result in hardship for some newly arrived residents. In the Committee's view these provisions were clearly enunciated during the election campaign and information on proposed changes to the policy have been widely circulated by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. The Committee notes that the provisions in the Bill relating to special benefits are prospective. Therefore new residents who arrive after 1 April 1996 and before the Royal Assent of the Bill will be eligible for special benefits under current arrangements. In the Committee's view, these provisions provide an appropriate transition and will allay concerns about this aspect of the Bill.".

The House of Representatives also notes that the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills made no adverse finding on any retrospective aspect of the provisions relating to newly arrived resident's waiting periods.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we begin debating this particular matter, I wish to make a statement in relation to equally divided votes. At this stage I believe that I ought to draw to the committee's attention the possible effect of votes which may be taken in relation to this bill.

INTERJECT.PARA: When Senate amendments to a bill first introduced in the House of Representatives are disagreed to by the House, the Senate has to decide whether to insist on its amendments. The standing orders provide for alternative motions to be moved to determine that question, but the substantive result is not affected by the form of the motion.

If a vote is taken on that question, and the votes are equally divided, the ruling of President Sibraa of 21 October 1993 applies. That ruling was upheld by a majority of the Senate at the time and subsequently by a unanimous report of the Procedure Committee.

BREAK.PARA: The ruling distinguishes between two types of amendments. The first type, which I will call type A, is a Senate request for an amendment or a Senate amendment which consists of an alteration to the text of a bill. Equally divided votes on the question whether the Senate insists on such a request or amendment means that the request or amendment is lost and the bill proceeds without it. The rationale of this is that such a request or amendment requires a majority to be carried in the first instance, and the equally divided vote indicates that the request or amendment no longer has the support of a majority.

The other type of amendment, which I will call type B, takes the form of striking out a self-contained item in a bill. An equally divided vote on the question whether the Senate insists on such an amendment means that the amendment is insisted on. The rationale of this is that such an amendment can be made by an equally divided vote in the first instance, as every such item in a bill must be carried by a majority, and the subsequent vote would indicate that the item still lacked majority support. Examples relating to this bill may make this clearer.

Senate amendment No. 21 to the bill left out an item of the bill and inserted a new item. It is therefore a type A amendment. This amendment required a majority to be carried in the first instance. An equally divided vote on the question whether the Senate insists on this amendment would indicate that the amendment now lacks majority support and the Senate would therefore not insist on the amendment.

Senate amendment No. 16 to the bill strikes out a division of the bill. The question put by the chair was that the division stand as printed. This question was negatived. It could have been negatived by an equally divided vote indicating that the division lacked majority support, and the division would have been left out by such a vote. This is therefore a type B amendment. If the question to determine whether the Senate insists on this amendment is negatived by an equally divided vote, this will indicate that the division still lacks majority support and the Senate insists on leaving out the division.

PARA.TAB: A complication may arise if the Senate's amendments to a bill consist of a mixture of type A amendments, amendments to the text, and type B amendments striking out self-contained items. This is the situation with the bill now before us. When the Senate determines whether to insist on its amendments, an equally divided vote means that the type A amendments, amendments to the text, are lost, while the type B amendments, amendments striking out items, are maintained. If that situation arises, the Senate may wish to consider its position and, in particular, to consider whether it wishes some amendments to proceed in the absence of others. I suggest that it would be appropriate for progress to be reported at that stage to allow senators time to consider the situation.
