SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) is having a few problems. Nothing highlights this better than his recent trade statement. At best, it could be described as administrative in nature. What this means is that, at a stage of the nation's history the likes of which it has not seen before, with immense opportunities for economic integration with our region, Australia is found to be wanting.

SPEECH.PARA: For most of the life of this nation, Australia has suffered under the tyranny of distance with regard to trade issues. The economic powerhouse of the European continent was not on the doorstep of Australia and, as a result, we often missed out on the best opportunities. With the growth of the tiger economies in South-East Asia, Australia no longer suffers from the tyranny of distance. Indeed, we have a geographic advantage that our European trading partners could only dream about.

However, rather than seizing this opportunity and exploiting our advantage, investing in Australian industry and encouraging export industries, this government and, indeed, Mr Fischer have taken a rather pedestrian approach to trade policy. This has never been better highlighted than with the release of the government's trade outlook statement last week. What this statement seeks to do is to administer rather than direct; it seeks to follow rather than to lead.

Essentially, the government and in particular Mr Fischer fail to understand the No. 1 priority in regard to trade issues. That No. 1 priority is of course jobs. Trade policy is not about nice statements with outdated and unrealistic targets, nor is it about satisfying overseas interests at the cost of domestic responsibilities. Rather, trade policy is about growth, and growth is about jobs.

We as a nation must accept that our domestic market is too small to provide a basis for growth on its own. For industry to survive, government must provide programs and incentives for Australian industry to progress overseas which will provide jobs domestically. Unfortunately, the outlook for trade is not good with this new government. Consequently, the outlook for jobs is poor.

The 1996 Howard budget forecasts that the net export contribution to national economic growth in 1996-97 will fall to a negative three‐quarters of one per cent. This is a net loss. By comparison, in 1995-96 the figure was a positive one per cent. In just under a year this government, and in particular Mr Fischer, has orchestrated a dramatic slump in Australia's export growth. Nothing better illustrates the mind-set of this government and its attitude than these figures. That mind-set, of course, is a bean‐counter mentality to government, rather than one which initiates policy designed to support Australian business and industry and to encourage growth.

Without the commitment to industry support and a proactive approach to economic policy in general, the commitments of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in regards to jobs ring hollow. How, Prime Minister, can jobs be created when industry and investment is being discouraged?

Of course, with this government, the bad figures in relation to export contribution to economic growth do not stop there. In last week's Mid‐year economic and fiscal outlook 1996‐97 there was a negative forecast of one-quarter of one per cent for 1996-97. Admittedly, the figure has improved by half a per cent. However, the forecast is still a negative figure and any improvement stems from a drop in imports rather than any successful trade policy.

The government's trade statement is notable for the fact that it comes after a terrible year of government trade policy. Rather than make amends for this matter, it does nothing to recognise the problems or solve them. This is particularly strange because the government's attacks on the industry and trade sector over the past 12 months have been notable for their savageness and short‐sightedness.

For example, who could forget the DIFF program shambles? Here was a highly successful initiative by the former federal government—an initiative designed to improve Australian industry competitiveness in the export sphere and an initiative designed to assist the nations in our immediate region where we were seeking to engage in bilateral and multilateral trade agreements. It was an initiative that was looked upon favourably and, indeed, relied upon in many circumstances by the respective governments in the region. However, the government chose to cut the program. The cost was a severe embarrassment for Australia and a lack of credibility within the region in which we sought to economically integrate ourselves through our trade and industry policies.

As I mentioned earlier, at a time when finally the geographical circumstances were in our favour, the government finds a way to destroy an excellent program which greatly enhances Australia's position within the region. Unfortunately for Australian industry and, ultimately, Australian jobs, the lack of initiative and action with regard to trade policy did not stop there. There was, of course, backsliding and embarrassment in regard to Howe Leather, involvement with the European Union, cuts to Austrade and a wide cross-section of other programs designed and successfully enhancing Australian industry and exports.

Of course, who could forget the mess over the ships bounty? Here was a government incentive and assistance program not only designed to assist but actually assisting our export orientated industry, which was gaining a reputation for excellence throughout the world. In accordance with the government's bean counter mentality, the assistance was cut to meet the government's budget bottom line objective. What it did was cut a program which contributed towards a high growth, export orientated industry which had a growth rate of 200 per cent, exports of 150 per cent and employment growth levels of over 50 per cent per annum. Additionally, the cuts threatened jobs and the competitiveness of an Australian success story. For a $3 million saving, which is a paltry sum in comparison to the total national budget, jobs and exports were going to be destroyed.

It may be possible to argue that in the early stages of a government mistakes will be made and novices will have to learn the ropes. Though after 12 months of disastrous trade and industry policy decisions, the government did not use this statement to make policy corrections. It did not seek to rectify problems of the past and change tack to provide a direction from government for Australian export orientated industry.

Mr Fischer did little with his statement. If nothing else, the statement could have been used to dispel some of the myths abounding about the government at the moment. For example, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Anderson, has recently made comments suggesting that Australia should rely on primary product exports rather than developing our processing industries, which would result in value added products being produced by Australia. The argument was that we should not seek to create new value added industries. Rather, we should continue with the old Menzian ideology, which was dig it up, ship it out and buy it back in some other form at a cost to the Australian community. This is exactly the type of attitude which took so long to correct through the 1980s, with policies seeking South-East Asian economic integration, and created many of the problems we still have today.

Rather than dispel this silly notion and make some commitment or even comment in regard to the desirability of a value adding sector, Mr Fischer ignored the issue and, consequently, the challenge facing Australia. Even if Mr Fischer had ignored the challenges relating to value added exports, he could have at least drawn attention to the fact that the forecast for commodity prices on which Mr Anderson would have Australia base its future is not particularly good. Indeed, Mr Fischer's statement on page 22 states:
. . . relatively modest outlook for commodity prices.
My own state of Western Australia will, indeed, be affected by this lack of vision by the Deputy Prime Minister, which one assumes is approved of by Mr Howard.

Western Australia is a primary resources state. It has vast reserves of minerals and is a world leader in their exportation. The state's chances for growth in the long term, however, depend on its ability to go to the next stage with these resources. Rather than ship them off and buy them back when they have been through the value adding phase at a net cost to the Australian community, the state and, indeed, the nation must learn to create those manufacturing industries in my home state of Western Australia and around the nation. There was, of course, no comment in regard to these issues. Mr Fischer's lack of interest in Western Australia is the best reason yet why the National Party fails to gain any representation from that state.

In the other important area of research and development, it was only late last year that the Howard government highlighted its view in this area. Once again, the bean counter mentality dictated to the cabinet that the tax rebate for R&D should be reduced to 125 per cent rather than maintained at 150 per cent. Australia must learn from its surrounding nations. Their success can provide an excellent case study for Australia on how to encourage and support industry and business to better position itself in the new trading world. In these tiger economies, initiatives like research and development tax rebates are an important part of that progress. Rather than learn from these successful nations, the Howard government, which has handed its trade policy to Mr Fischer, has thumbed its nose at these successes and done the opposite. A better illustration of the government's mentality I cannot find.

Australian industry and business must have serious concerns now about their futures and their successes. As many of them are making the transition into a competitive region and a competitive world, they are looking to government for support, direction, incentives and leadership. They have received none. This statement was their opportunity to have their interests put back on the agenda as priorities of the government and to assist them in creating jobs for Australians. Instead, they are now left directionless, with little hope of improvement.

Australian business and industry should not be the enemy of this government or the community. They should be recognised as integral to our national growth. Their success is our success, their wealth is our wealth and their growth is our jobs. By letting Australian industry down, the government has let down Australians who are currently unemployed and those who are facing structural changes in their respective industries. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday, I asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Parer, representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Anderson, a question in the chamber. It was a serious question, although with the answer I got I am not sure whether the minister took it seriously at all. His answer said nothing, but the question remains.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very serious question because the ABARE conference, which was held last week, forecast a very grim future for our primary and rural industry. My question concerned whether or not it was the fault of the government that this was so, because, to date, it has not produced any policies to correct this situation. I even gave the minister an opportunity to make a statement. I suppose in that sense it was a dorothy dixer. I asked the minister, `What are you going to do?' But of course I got a rambling answer about nothing, and certainly no answer to the plight of our farmers in Australia.

Australia's primary producers are facing falling exports, financial losses this financial year, according to the figures released by ABARE, and a very bleak future indeed. For example, I will just read some comments about the conference from the Australian last week. It says:

BREAK.PARA: In the rural sector, falling world prices could see the net value of farm production slump by a massive 28.5 per cent in 1996-97, despite a 9 per cent increase in the volume of farm production.

Farmers could see the value of their production value slashed by around $3 billion, with a further 17 per cent reduction in 1997-98. On average, business losses of $4700 are predicted for this financial year, after a sharp turnaround in 1995-96 following the easing of drought conditions and buoyant world prices.
Farm exports are also expected to drop by just over 1 per cent to $20.2 billion this financial year, with no export growth likely in 1997‐98.

I would have thought that, since I had drawn those conditions to the attention of the minister, he would have had a briefing paper which would have given some answers to the Senate and certainly to farmers in Australia. Although I asked a question that should have provided him with an opportunity to present those policy options and those answers, I got what the ABARE conference had got from the minister a few days previously, and that is nothing.

The Senate should be appalled by the non-answer given in this place and by Minister Anderson's failure to take action to address the rural crisis. At a media conference after the devastating rural outlook was delivered, he said that there is little his government can do. Mr Anderson told the conference that he was enormously worried—I am sure he is—about the outlook for farmers. He said:
The reality is that there is little we can do at home until global demand picks up and so there are no magic wands for farmers.

I must tell the Senate that what farmers want is certainly not magic wands. They do not want John Anderson to be Tinkerbell. They want real policy solutions. Let me continue with more of what Mr Anderson said. He said that Australian farmers are `at the mercy of world markets'.

After being given the devastating news that almost all rural sectors will suffer more financial losses this year, farmers have been treated to the sight of their National Party minister throwing his hands up in the air and saying, `Sorry, guys, there is nothing I can do about it.' When will the primary industries minister, John Anderson, admit that his government has done Australian farmers and his party supporters a grave disservice by failing to address the rural decline and wilfully leaving primary producers to the mercy of an unfair market?

I even pointed out to the minister in this place, in my question last week, three areas where there has been dumping in Australian markets. Where is the anti‐dumping legislation we were promised during the election? It is yet to be seen; it is yet to see the light of day. When will this government see the folly of pursuing pure economic theory and thinking that some kind of macho free trade competition with other nations will provide an answer, when week after week, month after month and year after year we see our markets and our industries at the mercy of that same so-called free trade competition, which is certainly not fair trade. Let me point out that those nations with which we compete are certainly not as keen as we are to throw their farmers on the scrap heap.

What I want to know is when this government will see the devastating ABARE figures for what they are: a warning call that the Australian farming industry is in grave danger of being irreparably damaged if real corrective action is not taken, and taken soon. Also last week, ABARE released figures showing that the population in rural and regional Australia has decreased by around 40 per cent in the past 20 years. The policies of both Labor and the coalition have not arrested the appalling situation where we continue to suck people out of our rural areas and dump them in our cities and on unemployment benefit to further increase the pressure on our city infrastructures.

Farmers need practical help with their problems with finance, with unfair competition and with the loss of rural services. Certainly, this last couple of weeks, as we have been around part of regional Australia looking at the government announcement that it is going to sell the Commonwealth railways, we have heard from rural and regional areas that they cannot cope with the loss of one more service; that, in fact, they have been stripped to the bone and that, if any further services are to be removed, it really means the total collapse of our regional infrastructure.

These issues are just as responsible for the rural decline as any unfair competition in world markets. I will admit that the rural crisis is partly due to cyclical and international factors, but I say to the Senate that this has been exacerbated by the economic rationalist and free trade policies of this government and of the previous Labor government.

The federal government's macho posturing on free trade is having a devastating effect for domestic farmers, who are being exposed to unfair competition at a time when they are most vulnerable. There are obvious benefits from trade liberalisation, but our strategy must factor in the domestic situation or our farmers are not going to survive the free trade push.

I believe we are facing a rural exodus similar to those which occurred in the United States following the severe droughts and downturn in the 1920s which led to massive social upheaval. I do not think it is too much to refer to John Steinbeck's novel about this time in which he speaks of the grapes of wrath situation. That is the kind of situation we are facing if this government does not wake up to what is happening to our rural communities and our Australian farmers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening in the wake of the government's announcement on the work for the dole scheme. Just as Senator Woodley has called on the government to adopt real policy solutions in respect of his issue, I am doing the same in respect of the work for the dole scheme on the issue of unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear from what has happened that the government have lost their way and have lost the plot. What they have done, in effect, is confirmed for the Australian people their inability to create jobs or assist in the creation of jobs. Quite obviously, they have thrown in the towel very early, after having been elected only last March, because this is not the sort of issue that you would think they would grab for after merely nearly 11 months in government.

BREAK.PARA: The government has a moral obligation, believe it or not, to provide real jobs, just as it has the obligation to provide real policy solutions. The fact is that work is diminishing in our society and that the nature of work has changed dramatically. This needs to be addressed. The government needs to address the cause of the problem rather than use a bandaid approach to overcome the difficulties that beset our community. There is no reason why it should use stop-gap measures, such as working for the dole, to overcome the unemployment problem that besets us.

The only work available would be work that people otherwise would be genuinely employed in and paid for. In other words, under this work for the dole scheme, those people who would genuinely pick up real jobs will be excluded. What we will see in the longer term is a negative impact. If real work is not available, then paying dole recipients to participate in useless tasks seems to me to be a pretty useless sort of exercise in itself.

We are faced with a government which does not know how to deal with the issue. All it can do is look to simplistic solutions to what it sees as the problem. It does not want to look beyond the simplistic solutions because that might involve too much difficulty within its own ranks.

There are practical problems in the solution that has been put up by the government of getting people to work for the dole. It is not the panacea that it is painted to be. The issue has been already raised of voluntary versus compulsory work for the dole. For whom is it going to be voluntary? For whom is it going to be compulsory? Where will it be voluntary? Where will it be compulsory? Will it be compulsory in the country and the regional centres? If so, why? Why not in the main cities? When will it be compulsory for people? What days of the week? What time of the day? No-one knows.

Here we have an ill-conceived scheme with the government not really knowing what they are doing, plucking out a bit of an idea at the last moment which they think may well be their saviour. There are further practical problems. Who is going to meet the fares? Who is going to meet the cost of people pre senting for work? Who is going to pay for the clothing these people will need to present for the work they are offered under the work for the dole scheme? Who is going to pay the cost of protective clothing if it is needed? No-one knows and no-one will know the answer to these questions because the government have not thought this through.

There is a cost associated with a person presenting themselves for work. Who is going to pay this cost to people who are already on a meagre income to start with, being on employment benefits? I believe that this just goes to show that the government have not thought the issue through.

Another practical problem that the scheme will face is the cost of training if training is needed in the work that is to be provided under the work for the dole scheme. If there is going to be training, then this would imply to me that a real job should be available and that it should not be a work for the dole scheme job; it should be a real job that goes to a genuinely unemployed person for their long-term benefit.

Then we must consider what the rates of pay will be. If we are getting people into jobs that are going to involve training, then what realistically would be the rates of pay that these people should receive? In other words, it implies that they should be remunerated for their degree of skill rather than simply palmed off by being paid a substandard wage or a substandard pittance by way of the unemployment benefit.

Further problems that need to be faced include the following. Who is going to be responsible for the work contract and with whom will the work contract relationship exist? Who is, in effect, going to be the employer? Who is going to pay the workers compensation? Who is going to meet the cost of superannuation? Who is going to take the responsible for occupational health and safety? These questions are all totally unanswered and, of course, will further complicate this very simplistic idea of work for the dole. Basically the scheme presents itself as a cut‐price labour scheme, and that is about the best tag that could be attached to it.

The government need to address the real issue in this. They need to start addressing the issue of the downsizing that is taking place in an unfettered manner throughout the workplace by employers. That is one of the first things that they need to do. The second thing that they need to do is address what work will be available for people in our community in the future, and I do not think the government have seriously thought of even addressing this issue.

Last but not least, the government need to address the real issue that this concept of work for the dole is not used as a means of manipulating the unemployment figures, because unemployment in itself is a major crisis for the person. It is the person who suffers; it is the person whose dignity is lost as a result of unemployment. It would be sad to see this scheme proceed purely as a means by which the government could manipulate the unemployment figures.

So what we have with what was announced over the weekend is really Fightback revisited. It shows no vision; it shows no imagination; it shows no hope. It is what one would expect from a government who finds itself in crisis on the unemployment issue after only 11 months in government. It is what one would expect from a government that lacks policies and vision in this area and offers no hope to those people who find themselves continually on the unemployed list. Undoubtedly this issue will come up further in this chamber, but I could not let this opportunity pass without making a few brief comments about the recent government decision.

The government need to get their act together. They need to think about people. They need to think of the dignity of people and the cost of what working for the dole will really mean to people. It will mean a destruction of the individual's personality, their self-regard and their ability to participate in a meaningful way in our society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to focus the attention of the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) on his responsibilities in rela tion to the environmental impact of Operation Tandem Thrust. Operation Tandem Thrust is a major defence exercise that will take place off the coast of Queensland. It is specifically in the Shoalwater Bay training area. It will involve 26,000 defence personnel, 20 major warships and 13 minor warships.

SPEECH.PARA: I do have in my possession an executive summary of the environmental issues involved in exercise Tandem Thrust. While I welcome the fact that there is such a document, I only have the executive summary and I have to say this summary raises more questions and more concerns than it answers. I would like to just run through some of these tonight.

In the opening statement it says that this is not the largest exercise that has been conducted in this area, but I would like to make the point that it is the only exercise that has been carried out in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Other exercises that were carried out were carried out in the 1970s, and we had very different attitudes, standards and practices in relation to what we expected and how we expected activities to take place in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.
I would like to detail what the naval operations will consist of. The summary states:
Naval operations will occur both inside and outside the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park . . .

The Carrier Battle Group will enter the park to conduct "choke point transit" operations, and to launch and recover aircraft. The Carrier Battle Group operations will include surface warfare, undersea warfare and air warfare operations. Carrier based aircraft will conduct operations inside SWBTA—
the Shoalwater Bay training area—
These operations will include the dropping of live ordnance onto the impact areas.
Surface combatants will enter the GBRMP—
the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park—

to conduct naval surface fire support missions on the impact area on Townshend Island. It is planned to launch amphibious assaults, live naval gunfire support (NGS), aerial bombing, and electronic warfare operations from within the GBRMP.

You can see why I am concerned that there has not been full public debate about some of these issues, and there has been limited accountability on the part of the Minister for the Environment, who does have responsibility for the marine park.

As I said, I acknowledge the efforts that are being made, but I think we have a long way to go before many of us would be reassured about some of the planning involved. There is to be an environmental monitoring group, and those roles and responsibilities are set out. They include, among other items, to respond to reported environmental incidents and instigate and coordinate subsequent remedial action. Quite clearly, the defence forces are expecting environmental incidents because they are already predicting them.
The environmental monitoring group will also:

undertake active inspections of the exercise area to detect unnoticed or unreported adverse environmental impacts and subsequently instigate appropriate remedial measures to prevent or minimise damage;

Clearly, that is welcome but it might be preferable if the minister would take responsibility and ensure that we have a fully documented statement of how this exercise is going to take place and how the damage to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park is going to be minimised—and I am not very happy about using that term myself. Clearly, we need a great deal more information.
Furthermore, there is some reference to the group's role to:
resolve issues of cost‐sharing for environmental repairs and mitigation measures identified during pre and post‐exercise inspections;

Every senator would be aware that a reef tax is being imposed on tourists visiting the Great Barrier Reef. It seems that we are going to have 26,000 military tourists. If they were to pay the full cost of the reef tax, that would recoup the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority in the vicinity of about a million dollars. Is this what is proposed, or is it going to be dependent on how much damage is done?

That is just one example of how uncertain the whole planning process seems to have been. I sympathise with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority because, I presume, they have simply been told that they have to along with it because it is a Defence exercise and Defence calls the shots, if you will forgive the pun.

On page 8 of this executive summary, under the heading `Protection of Marine Mammals, Endangered/Threatened Species,' it is acknowledged that there are many of these species in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. The summary indicates that there is a critically endangered population of 400 dugongs living in the Shoalwater Bay training area. The summary says:

It is a most important population. It is the most important population remaining in the Southern Great Barrier Reef. The feeding areas most often frequented by dugong will generally not be used during the exercise as they occur in shallow waters where shipping would be vulnerable to grounding.
Clearly, the author of this document is more concerned about the grounding of ships than the state of the endangered species. It continues:

To further minimise potential impacts, the location and speed of boat operations in these areas will be restricted. There is also a potential risk to these species when underwater demolition charges are detonated . . .
I should imagine that is the understatement of the year. The summary continues:

Although there has been no record of injury or mortality of these species as a result of underwater demolitions since the range was established in the early 1970's, underwater detonations will be restricted to Triangular Island . . .
It goes on to talk about endangered turtles. Turtles—I am sorry but this would be a joke if it were not so serious—will:
not be approached, impeded or interfered with in any way.
Frankly, if you consider what the turtles are facing—26,000 defence personnel, 20 major warships and 30 minor warships—I am not sure if the turtles will have much say in the matter, but I digress.

What to me seems to be important is that the minister be fully briefed. He was obviously not briefed this afternoon when my colleague Senator Meg Lees raised an issue related to a ship that is being refuelled within the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and about live ammunition being taken off by helicopter in the vicinity of residential areas of Townsville, although I am told that has been done in a totally responsible way. You wonder whether this was part of the planning. If so, why do members of the Townsville City Council know nothing of these plans?

I would be calling for the minister to release for full public scrutiny this document, Environmental issues: exercise Tandem Thrust 97. I call on him to make a comprehensive statement about how his department will enforce the management plan, pick up on many of the concerns that I do not have the time to detail this evening and announce what financial contribution will be made for overseeing environmental protection and any clean‐up measures. There is a need for this issue to be fully scrutinised and fully debated. Just because it is a defence exercise does not mean that we should not have the opportunity to ensure that these proposed actions will not damage the reef or endangered species within it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 25 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the Minister's answer to Senator Brown's question without notice on Tasmania's Mount McCall Road (Senate Hansard , 29 October 1996, pp. 4638-4639):

(a) What were the Minister's reasons for revisiting this issue when a legally-binding decision on it was made in 1992, when the management plan for the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Areas was approved;
(b) what advice has the Minister received from his portfolio on this issue and can a copy of that advice be provided; and
(c) what additional advice has the Minister sought from the portfolio on this issue.

(2) With reference to the announcement by the Minister, on 7 November 1996, that agreement had been reached with the Tasmanian Government on the environmental assessment process for the proposed Tasmanian pulp mill: can a copy of that agreement be provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)(a) The consideration of this issue at the Ministerial Council meeting in September last year, stems from the opinion of the Tasmanian Government that recent studies commissioned into the closure of the road may yield new information on the environmental and economic impacts of such action. These studies will become available for the consideration of the next Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area Ministerial Council in March 1997. Any final decision on this issue needs to be made by the whole Council—as the Commonwealth Environment Minister, I cannot act unilaterally in this matter.
(b) I have been briefed by my department on this issue. It is not, however, standard practice to release the department's internal working documents.
(c) The department will be providing me with further briefings in the context of the next Ministerial Council.
(2) A copy of the agreement has been provided to the honourable senator and additional copies are available from the Senate Table Office.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 23 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to each of the restricted shipment licences to export woodchips issued in 1996:
(1) On what date was each licence application received and from which person.
(2) What was the purpose specified by the applicant for each of the licences and for what purpose was each licence issued.
(3) What was the name of the person to whom each licence was issued and on what date was each licence issued.

(4) For each licence: (a) what is the quantity; (b) from where can the woodchips be sourced; (c) what is the port of export; (d) what are the start and finish dates; (e) what prospective market is being trialed; and (f) to which person will the shipment be exported.
(5) What terms and conditions apply to each licence; please provide a copy of the licences.

(6) For each licence: (a) on what dates and in what documents did the department provide advice in writing to the Minister in respect of each of these licences; (b) can a copy be provided of each document listed in (a); if not, please describe the matters covered in each document; (c) on what dates and in what documents did the Minister or the department receive any advice in writing from the Department of the Environment or Minister for the Environment in respect of each of these licences; (d) can a copy be provided of each document listed in (c); if not, please describe the matters covered in each document; (e) on what dates and in what documents did the Minister or the department receive advice in writing from any State government or local government in respect of each of these licences; and (f) can a copy be provided of each document listed in (e); if not, please describe the matters covered in each document.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Three applications have been received for restricted shipment licences. On 13 September 1996, an application for a restricted shipment licence was received from the WA Chip and Pulp Co Pty Ltd (WACAP). On 30 October, 1996, Gerry PF O'Shaughnessy, trading as Maintenance Services (Maintenance Services) applied for a restricted shipment licence. Finally, a single application from Artec Pty Ltd (Artec) for two restricted shipment licences was received on 14 November 1996.
(2) All applications were for the purpose of trialing a prospective market and all four licences were issued for that purpose.

(3) A licence (MEPWOOD 1434) was granted to WACAP on 15 October 1996. A licence (MEPWOOD 1471) was granted to Maintenance Services on 12 December 1996. Two licences (MEPWOOD 1476 and MEPWOOD 1477) were granted to Artec on 13 December 1996.

MEPWOOD 1471: 10,000 tonnes, restricted to 1 shipment;
MEPWOOD 1476: 34,000 tonnes, restricted to 1 shipment;
MEPWOOD 1477: 26,000 tonnes, restricted to 1 shipment;
(b) MEPWOOD 1434: Restricts material for export to jarrah hardwood woodchips derived from sawmill residues and drawn from the stockpile at Bunnings Forest Products' Deanmill sawmill;
MEPWOOD 1471: Restricts material for export to hardwood wood chips derived from sawmill waste and burned and damaged forest residue timber sourced from the East Gippsland region;
MEPWOOD 1476 and MEPWOOD 1477: Restricts material for export to hardwood wood chips sourced from nominated stockpiles firstly at Bell Bay and secondly at Lilydale sawmills in Tasmania;
(c) MEPWOOD 1434: Nominated by the applicant to be exported from Bunbury, although not specified in licence;
MEPWOOD 1471: Not specified in licence;
MEPWOOD 1476 and MEPWOOD 1477: Nominated by the applicant to be exported from Bell Bay, although not specified in licences;

(d) MEPWOOD 1434: Start date is 15 October 1996; finish date is 30 June 1997; MEPWOOD 1471: Start date is 1 January 1997; finish date is 31 December 1997. MEPWOOD 1476 and MEPWOOD 1477: Start date is 13 December 1996; finish date is 31 December 1997;
(e) MEPWOOD 1434: Saudi Arabia; MEPWOOD 1471: Saudi Arabia; MEPWOOD 1476: South Korea; MEPWOOD 1477: Taiwan;
(f) MEPWOOD 1434, MEPWOOD 1471, MEPWOOD 1476 and MEPWOOD 1477: Not provided due to commercial sensitivity.
(5) Refer to edited copies of MEPWOOD 1434, MEPWOOD 1471, MEPWOOD 1476 and MEPWOOD 1477 attached. Commercially sensitive material has been deleted.

For MEPWOOD 1471: On 26 November 1996, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy provided a Minute and attachments;
For MEPWOOD 1476 and MEPWOOD 1477: On 12 December 1996, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy provided a Minute and attachments;

(b) A copy of each document will not be provided, but the matters contained in the Minutes went to the background behind the applications, matters relevant to my obligations under the Export Control Act 1982 and Regulations, the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, and the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, and recommendations to grant WACAP, Maintenance Services and Artec the restricted shipment licences sought. Attachments detailed the applications from WACAP, Maintenance Services and Artec and letters from the companies concerning same. Further, in relation to the Artec application, attachments comprised letters from the Port of Launceston Authority, and the Judgment of Underwood J of the Supreme Court of Tasmania on 19 November 1996;

(c) As no additional harvesting was to be involved if the licences were granted and the licences were to include a condition requiring the exporter to ensure its operations do not threaten endangered species, no advice was sought from the Department of the Environment or the Minister for the Environment in respect of these applications;
(d) Not applicable;
(e) No direct advice was received from any State government or local government in respect of these applications;
(f) Not applicable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 14 January 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the forward estimates for the following program elements: (a) National Landcare Program; (b) Vertebrate Pest Program; (c) Murray‐Darling Basin Initiative; and (d) Rural Adjustment Scheme.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: For (a), (b), (c), forward estimates are currently either unavailable or not reliable, pending the passing of the Natural Heritage Trust Bill and finalisation of the 1997‐98 Budget process. The senator's attention should be drawn to the 1997‐98 Portfolio Budget statements once they have been published.

In response to (d), at the 1996‐97 Budget the appropriation for "normal" RAS was $56.332m. The forward estimates for 1997‐98, 1998‐99, and 1999‐00 were $45.735m, $54.116m and $56.598m respectively. These estimates were changed in the process of developing the 1996‐97 Additional Estimates. An additional $11.5m to be split equally between 1996‐97 and 1997‐98 was included for "normal" RAS, following the Government's decision, announced on 4 November 1996, to extend the drought recovery period.
